reviewText: Director Villeneuve has you from the opening scenes of two families (1 black & 1 white) gathering for Thanksgiving in a Pennsylvania suburb, and the natural, easy joy they have in each other's company. But once you are aware a kidnapping has occurred, you are ALL IN until the harrowingly redemptive conclusion.There is a strong thread of Judeo-Christian understanding informing this film, and it is pretty tough stuff. Not an ounce of easy reassurance in the script, performances, the ominous score or top-notch cinematography. You'll hear a telling section from the book of Job on a car radio. I thought the theological hints from earlier in the film should've been present in the closing scenes, too - it wasn't - but attentive and perceptive viewers will realize that, in addition to the masterful suspense, you have met some serious evil in this film. And this evil scars and deforms everyone, including the protagonists. Redemption in this life costs a lot, and the success of PRISONERS is that you understand this by the time the credits roll.For me, best film of the year as of 9/26/13! But NOT for those looking for a night of pleasant entertainment.
summary: oscars all around! - seamless suspense + a bit of theology

reviewText: For a film that is over two and a half hours long, there are so many plot holes in ‘Prisoners’ I’m almost tempted to wish that it was three hours in length, and then again, maybe I just wish that it had never been made.  Watching the film in the first place took inner strength, since the subject matter is one that I have a very strong reaction to, but I expected to at least be rewarded with a thought provoking film that tested my inner calm but delivered a strong impact.Instead, I was left with confusion, frustration and indifference.Honestly, it was like screenwriter Aaron Guzikowski and director Denis Villeneuve thought that if you throw enough unnecessary details into a pot and stir them, the audience won’t notice the plot holes because they’ll be as distracted as Detective Loki by a bunch of stuff that makes no sense and means absolutely nothing.The premise of ‘Prisoners’ is a relatively simple one.  The Dover’s and the Birch’s are neighbors and friends.  They hang out a lot, apparently.  One day, while they are socializing at the Birch residence, their young daughters leave to find a lost whistle and wind up missing.  They search to no avail and then the police are brought in and despite having a lead, there is nothing solid and no real evidence that they can get their hands on and Keller Dover soon feels the need to take matters into his own hand.  In a move that many fathers in this position would contemplate but never actually act out, Keller kidnaps the prime suspect, locks him in an abandoned building, and tortures him for answers he won’t divulge.  Keller just KNOWS that this young man (who is obviously mentally handicapped) has the answers to where these little girls are and so he continues to beat and torture him despite getting nothing out of him.  The Birch family becomes involved, but they remain at a distance (or at least as much as possible).  In the meantime, Detective Loki becomes consumed with unraveling the mystery of these vanished girls and follows up on the few leads he gets only to find himself preoccupied by the suspicious activity of Keller himself.As the days tick by, the prospect of finding these girls alive grows slim.I have SO MANY issues with this film that discussing them would almost take an entire day, but I’ll try and just sputter.  It really all boils down to a film about complete incompetence.  First off, these parents are kind of dense.  You let your little girls leave the house to wander down the street in search of a whistle, and despite the fact that you make it clear you never let them wander off alone you forget they ever left until hours have gone by, even with the knowledge of a creepy van on the street?  That doesn’t make sense to me at all.  Be attentive!  Next, Loki seems to be the ONLY person on the police team to be remotely interested in seeing these girls reunited with their families.  Despite having a suspect, they drop the ball and don’t even tail him, allowing him to be kidnapped and have the police be none the wiser.  Next, you have a suspect with a creepy van parked outside of his Aunt’s home, and she admits that he does that all the time, and yet you don’t investigate her house or her property for clues?  How is that?  Shouldn’t that have been the FIRST thing you did, even if you didn’t suspect her of anything?  Then you have Keller, who does what every man in that situation is thinking, and yet you allow yourself to become a complete monster by brutally assaulting a man who is three shades away from going full retard?  I mean, how does that solve anything?  This is an issue with me because you basically have a man beating on a child to get answers as to what he supposedly did with a child.  Maybe this is the moral dilemma we are supposed to face, but the film seems so uninterested in making Keller anything more than the savior of his children.Incompetence, both in character and in filmmaking.But let’s get into that incompetent filmmaking for a minute.  What about all those ‘details’ that are all over the place?  You can spin your wheels all you want and color in every surface and draw those mazes all over the place, but at the end of the day it all feels like a waste of time.  Let’s have this creepy guy buy kid’s clothes and sneak into the victim’s homes that so the audience will think he had something to do with it only to have him off himself before he explains anything to anyone and then just drop it without really explaining anything (yes, I know who he was…but what was he doing in the Dover and Birch residence?).  Let’s throw mazes all over the walls and then shows a flashback with a book of mazes and a creepy message and then…not explain what the mazes have to do with anything!  Let’s give the kidnapper this ridiculous backstory and then never talk about it past a solitary comment.Let’s spend two and a half hours doing absolutely nothing but giving the impression that we are doing a LOT!And don’t even get me started on the ending.  This is what I mean about these holes in plot that just don’t add up.  Keller discovers the truth, but instead of informing the police and rushing to the rescue with Loki, he runs FROM the police and goes there alone, only to dig himself into a very deep hole (literally) and then, when all is said and done it takes quite a bit of time before the police do anything about investigating the area in which the crime took place (once again, wouldn’t that be the FIRST thing you did?).That stupid whistle.But the ensemble is great, right?  Sort of.  They all work to an extent, but the only one who really does a lot with what he’s given is Jake Gyllenhaal.  He actually works to flesh out Loki and his obsessions, while the others tend to give a glossed over variation of a solitary emotion.  Jackman yells and glares and then prays.  Davis cries.  Howard awkwardly holds his mouth in shock and looks like he wants to pee in his pants.  Maria Bello kind of disappears from the whole movie only to reappear as a loon.  Paul Dano doesn’t have the chance to do much but look scared and scream.  Melissa Leo gets saddled with a ridiculous character, and while she sells it I’m not quite sure I care for what she’s selling.Conceptually, ‘Prisoners’ had promise.  As a father (of two young girls about the age of the ones kidnapped here), I was not looking forward to watching this.  My biggest fear is something like this.  Abuse is bad enough, but not knowing where and what is happening to your children is the WORST feeling in the world, and I have to admit, I was totally TEAM KELLER for the first half of this film, but ‘Prisoners’ doesn’t know how to develop this concept in a way that feels authentic or even intelligent.  It all just feels so stupid.
summary: Someone doesn’t know how to make a movie…

reviewText: I had high hopes for this movie. Why? Because Jake Gyllenhaal has one sick tattoo stuck to the side of his neck. And homemade hillbilly knuckle tats. I have hillbilly blood in my genes, so this character could have been a member of my family. Or even myself.Detective Loki is no ordinary cop. This dude is a super sleuth. Hugh Jackman is ultra-realistic as the dad who is beside himself when his daughter goes missing. Keller Dover uses father's intuition to track down the S.O.B. he thinks is responsible for his kid's disappearance. Then he lays the smack down on his dirty ass.Paul Dano plays the prime suspect, Alex Jones. Dim-witted, soft-spoken, with dorky glasses, this guy is definitely chester material. Jones is the type of individual who would orbit your child's playground during recess in a windowless cargo van with the words "free candy" spray-painted on the side. Instead, this character stereotype gets a convenient upgrade and drives a beat-up RV. Jones and his prehistoric wheels are the only witness to the freak disappearance of 2 young girls. Times a-ticking away when Dover decides to take matters into his own hands and relapses into a booze-fueled game of cat-and-mouse.You would think this movie's subject matter would be depressing, but it features enough scenery-chewing and action to keep this flick from making your heart sink. The characters are both bizarre and very memorable. The ending was neither overly optimistic nor sappy tearjerker. The 2 hour and 30 minute run time is a perfect length, and moves along at an optimized pace. Give this a shot. It's far more convincing than Gyllenhaal's last copper outing in the sub-parEnd of Watch.

reviewText: It could be at least 4 different people depending how you want to work with the definition of "prisoner!"  The angry father feels imprisoned as does his family since they can't find their missing daughter, the missing daughter could be interpreted as a prisoner, the cop would fit the bill as well since he's on the case but getting nowhere most of the time... even the bad guys!  Yes, "Prisoners" is an interesting title for the movie.Anyway without a DOUBT the number one reason Prisoners is such a great film is due to the extraordinary acting of Hugh Jackman.  When I say he's awesome in his role as the parent who desperately wants to find his missing daughter, I wasn't expecting him to basically turn into a possessed monster!  He will do absolutely *anything* to find her and can be deliberate, intense, angry, vengeful... you name it!  I knew Hugh Jackson was a fantastic actor- I think most of us knew that already going into Prisoners, but I guess I either had a lapse of judgment and forgot or just didn't realize how powerful he can be in the roles he plays, especially given the very frightening and realistic material he has to work with here.Hugh Jackson is so believable in his role that he should be winning best actor of the year for a role this good.  Maybe I just got caught up in the mystery and the suspense of the film so much that I'm simply blinded with bias so I apologize if it sounds like I'm exaggerating a bit, but he deserves *some* kind of accolade for his role.  Let's get to the movie instead of all this Hugh Jackman gushing shall we? :)I don't want to spoil what happens for a good chunk of the film but I might have to since not mentioning it is almost unavoidable.  This is a minor spoiler however, this next part.  Hugh finds and captures a mentally disturbed man who has the mindset of a 10-year old.  Hugh believes this man is responsible for the kidnapping of not only his daughter, but his friends daughter as well.  Hugh even hears the man singing a song that his daughter was singing the day she disappeared, sending distinct warning signs that he's the guilty one.  Hugh basically kidnaps and tortures the man, and keeps the body hidden in an old rundown and abandoned apartment building.  When Hugh's done torturing for the day, he returns the next day and keeps going without remorse.  Don't try to reason with Hugh either- he already thought the situation out clearly and won't let a simple disagreement that what he's doing is wrong stop him from processing with the torturing.  Basically Hugh's absolutely crazy in the head and proves he's willing to do anything to find his daughter.  He takes it to a whole new level!However the other major chunk of storytelling is about the cop (played by Jake Gyllenhaal) who ALMOST ruins the movie in my opinion due to his poor acting, nonchalant attitude, total disinterest in doing his job and finding the two daughters, feeling inconvenienced whenever Hugh Jackman expresses rage and accuses him of not trying hard enough (which is correct, the cop's NOT trying hard enough to find the two daughters- at least for a while).  Now some of this can be attributed to the storytelling- the writers wanted a laidback and lazy cop to search for clues in this small town.  However some of it is completely unintentional.  Jake just doesn't possess the right kind of emotions depending on the situation at hand.  He often comes across more like a rookie unaware how to react in certain situations.  Not sure if intentional or not.  I think someone else should have played the cop role instead.This movie even shows the mother/wife of Hugh Jackman, and how distraught and unable she is to cope with the disappearance of her daughter in believable fashion so she stays in bed depressed all the time.  While a good chunk of this movie is slow-moving, mystery-related drama, there's clearly *another* chunk of the writing that is suspenseful concerning how Hugh Jackman responds to the man he captures.  This is a mighty fine movie regardless of Jake Gyllenhaal almost dragging it down.  The only problem is the end of the film.  It doesn't provide the kind of closure that it clearly COULD have.  The movie needs at least one more minute to wrap everything up.  I mean they were *so* close!  Just one more minute would have done it!  Anyway the final 20 minutes are downright AWESOME despite the ending.  Several twists and turns.  Great great movie.

reviewText: If you like Fritz Lang and wish for his spirit in current filmmaking, look no further.  This film is extremely Langian, from the unsavory heroes who only find their own smallness and helplessness, not their redemption, to the plot twists that are so jaw-droppingly unbelievable they can only exist as material evidence of a fatalism that is beyond capricious.  Also, let's not forget the "mob mentality" a la Fury.  This is a film that sets out to be about very disturbing things and manages to be genuinely disturbing, and yet so fascinating that you feel almost uplifted by the absolute clarity of vision.  What I like best are the things that are never explained -- the strange, almost Night of the Hunter-like tattoos that the Gyllenhaal character wears, or the whereabouts of certain missing characters.  In this film everyone's a missing person until proven otherwise.

reviewText: "Prisoners" brings us some relatively new faces on the creative Hollywood scene and what they bring us is completely promising if not great. Veteran Coen Brothers cinematographer Roger Deakins lends his expertise to newcomer writer Aaron Guzikowski and Director Denis Villeneuve.  You can certainly see the influence of Deakins throughout the film and his beautiful take on reality in a chaotic situation.This is one of those films that you don't want to know a thing about before you go. You don't even want to hear people brushstroke over it because even that is something you don't want to hear. For that matter, I won't even go close to going there. I will give you a brief introduction to what you should expect. Keller Dover (Hugh Jackman) and his wife Grace (Maria Bello), walk down the street to their neighbors, Franklin Birch (Terrence Howard) and Nancy (Viola Davis). They each have a daughter and along the course of the evening, those two daughters disappear without a trace."Prisoners" is a gut-wrenching and fast running two and a-half hour movie. It is filmed in such a way that the events that unfold could involve you, your neighbor, somebody across town and on your local news.  Along with the way the movie is filmed and told, it is gifted with phenomenal actors that bring the reality of the situation to the surface.It is an exhausting an emotionally filled movie from top to bottom and its subject matter will have your stomach in knots until the credits roll.  This, quite simply, is what movies are all about. Too often these days, movies make you feel nothing. Too many directors and writers are concerned with what you see and forget that first and foremost, what makes great cinema and long lasting cinema, is the feeling it leaves in your stomach and soul. At one point, Keller Dover's sadness effected me so much that I felt as if I was actually him or in the least, one of his family members or a great friend."Prisoners" is the kind of movie we should be flocking to the theaters to see until Hollywood gets the message that we want to feel something.  Sure, dazzle us with visuals, but until you relay empathy in your audience members, you have wasted millions of dollars and time.  "Prisoners" is tremendous filmmaking. It is one of the best and most complete films of the year and will almost certainly be a member of the Oscar night nominees.
summary: A RARE THING  (a movie that actually invokes emotional involvement)

reviewText: The cast for "Prisoners" may be the most impressive ensemble of any film released in 2013. Hugh Jackman plays a father who is so committed to finding his daughter that he pushes himself beyond any sort of physical or mental limits any ordinary person may have had in the same situation. Jackman's performance is passionate, unstable, and driven. In fact, Jackman has never been better. Jake Gyllenhaal delivers a remarkable performance, as well. Detective Loki will stop at nothing to solve whatever case he's put on and he completely submerges himself in the investigation. The one thing that may stick out from Gyllenhaal's performance is the extreme way he blinks in certain situations. It may be an attribute of his character not getting enough sleep (his eyes appear really bloodshot at times, as well), but it's more than a little noticeable nevertheless.The rest of the cast seems to pick and choose their moments. Paul Dano's part is rather small, but the sleaziness Dano has become notorious for comes right along with him. Viola Davis portrays a mother at her wit's end perfectly. She has a fantastically emotional scene with Paul Dano that is superb. However, Maria Bello and Terrence Howard are a little disappointing. Bello mostly just whines and stays drugged up the entire film while Howard seems to repeat the same three lines of dialogue every time he opens his mouth. Howard has chosen some less than stellar projects to be a part of the past two years. It feels like he's still shaking off the absurd behavior and overall terribleness he was a part of in films like "Red Tails" and "Dead Man Down."Denis Velleneuve's crime thriller may seem exhausting looking at its 153-minute duration and it is in actuality a little long, but its pace is also very controlled. Think David Fincher's "Zodiac." It may be lengthy, but the performances are outstanding and the journey is never not intriguing. It's as if the viewers are attempting to piece together the clues that Detective Loki uncovers right as he discovers them and you're kept guessing until the very end.Other than the film's emphasis on mazes, religion is also an important factor of "Prisoners." Keller mutters The Lord's Prayer as his son Ralph (Dylan Minnette) shoots his first deer in the opening moments of the film and you also learn that Holly Jones (Melissa Leo), the aunt and current guardian of Alex Jones, used to be a devout Christian. "Waging a war on God," is something you find yourself pondering long after the film is over. After discussing the film with others, some may think the film focuses on torture a little too much. Truth be told, "Prisoners" would be completely different without the torture element. Alex Jones is the only lead anyone has for nearly the entire film, so naturally doing whatever it takes to make him talk seems reasonable. That doesn't mean it's not taken too far, but the reasoning is sound."Prisoners" is one of the most contemplative and fulfilling films of the year. While the film does leave you with a handful of questions, you'll find yourself thinking about the film days after you see it. Unpredictable and extraordinary, "Prisoners" throws you right into an unsolvable investigation that takes several unexpected turns.
summary: Pray for the best, but prepare for the worst

reviewText: Don't let the big-name stars fool you: PRISONERS has the trappings of a low-budget, independent character study, the kind that rarely finds its audience via the big screen.  Yet, thanks to word-of-mouth and Hugh Jackman, PRISONERS actually became something of a hit.  Goes to show you that occasionally, Hollywood gets it right.The film follows the Dover and Birch families, whose young daughters go missing over Thanksgiving.  The police quickly find a suspect, but don't have enough evidence to hold him.  Keller Dover, one of the grieving fathers, decides to take matters into his own hands, while determined police detective Loki follows up all possible leads.  The two stories frequently overlap, as suspects are eliminated and the case spirals ever onward.Let's get one thing straight: PRISONERS is about half an hour, maybe forty-five minutes too long.  There's a lot of padding here; granted, it's meant to be realistic ("hey, coincidences exist"), but it comes off as fluff meant to make this journey last a little longer.  That being said, the story here is a doozy, a solid script elevated by stellar acting.  As Dover, Hugh Jackman delivers a performance that slowly builds on itself.  His character's actions are never fully justified, but Jackman still gives the role a level of intensity that is both fantastic and off-putting (in a good way).  Paul Dano, as the prime suspect, disappears into his role, as he tends to do; every performance he gives is entirely different and captivating.  Viola Davis, Maria Bello, Terrence Howard, and especially Melissa Leo give fantastic turns.  But it is the film's other lead, Jake Gyllenhaal, who comes off as the true stand-out.  His performance is Oscar-worthy, at times over-the-top, yet on other occasions subtle and nuanced.  In a film filled with good actors doing great work, Gyllenhaal manages to stand out from the rest.A disclaimer, though: PRISONERS is not easy to watch.  Not because it's about child abduction, though that will upset some.  More so, it's the fact that PRISONERS doesn't shy away from moral complexities.  There are some thoroughly disturbing images (thanks to master cinematographer Roger Deakins) that will upset many viewers.  This isn't a film about black and white justice; it's a film about the grey area, about what people are willing to do for a good cause.  As such, PRISONERS is that rare mainstream film that tackles thoroughly complex issues.  True, by its third act, it becomes more of a conventional thriller...but before that?  It's something truly worth watching, right up until the final shot.

reviewText: "Prisoners" 2013 Fine Performances, Evocative Direction, Screwball ScriptI wanted to see "Prisoners" after I saw the trailer. Alas, the trailer contains all the best parts of the movie. Suburban parents celebrating Thanksgiving slowly come to realize that their two daughters are missing. The trailer featured quiet, dark scenes of increasing menace and despair, shot in realistic, autumnal, suburban settings. The trailer promised big, big stars: Hugh Jackman and Maria Bello as one set of parents and Viola Davis and Terence Howard as the other, Jake Gyllenhaal as the police detective, Paul Dano as the suspect and Melissa Leo as the suspect's adoptive parent. The trailer promised an intelligent thriller that would interrogate how far an ethical person could go in attempting to rescue his daughter from an abductor. The trailer also seemed to suggest an examination of how law enforcement responds, for better or worse, in child abduction cases.The first twenty minutes of "Prisoners" delivered what I'd hoped for based on the trailer, but I was hyper-aware that I was watching scene after scene I'd already seen in the trailer.Around the time that an unlikely body was found in an unlikely spot, and a fist met a face several times more than was necessary to make any point, but certainly enough times to satisfy a filmgoer's sick, sadistic bloodlust, the movie went off the rails for me, abandoned all its seriousness and intelligence, and became sensational gore and commercial pap. I was so let down I wanted to leave the theater, but I stayed because I'd roped two friends into seeing this with me."Prisoners" is a whodunit so there's a limit to what I can say without revealing any spoilers. I can say this. Jake Gyllenhaal powerfully performs a dedicated police detective. Hugh Jackman exercises his neck veins a lot, and his American accent is wobbly but okay. Terence Howard, Viola Davis, and Maria Bello are given criminally little to do. Viola Davis has one of the most interesting scenes in the movie. This scene is only a minute or two long and it is not developed at all. That is a shame because the scene is the moral crux of the film. And the film does nothing with it; the filmmakers went with implausible sensationalism and sadism rather than substance. Paul Dano, as the suspect, and Melissa Leo, as his adoptive mother, both give powerhouse performances in very challenging roles.Denis Villeneuve's direction is flawless. He avoids explosive stunts and theatrics with his camera. His moves are slow and quiet, even while filming ugly violence. I'd like to see his work on a better script.There are many attempts to make the movie deeper than it is. There are many scenes initially shot through dirty glass. "Through a glass darkly" is a line from the Bible. Ooo big symbolism. Wow. There are many crosses, including one hanging from the rearview mirror in Keller - Hugh Jackman's - truck. Wow. Heavy. I just may think something ... no, I'd rather watch snakes. Oh, yes. There are snakes. Some understand Satan as taking snake form in Genesis. Heavy. Profound! Yeah, not really. Just bizarrely implausible. There are strange character names. Hugh Jackman's first name is "Keller" which brings to mind the blind and deaf Helen Keller, or maybe the word "Killer." Jake Gyllenhaal is Detective Loki. Loki is the trickster God of Norse mythology. This is all pretty high school.There are two scenes and one character treatment in this film that I found completely implausible. The two scenes are essential to the plot. I can't describe these two scenes but I can say that one is utterly implausible because of surveillance. The action of the film takes place within hours and days of a child abduction. Not only police, but also media and neighbors would be keeping an eagle eye on all suspects. Another scene is implausible because it demands that we forget everything we've been told about a key character. One character treatment is unbelievable to me because a very unlikely character is depicted as being as heroic, in his way, as John McCain. Not plausible. I also found the final resolution of the crime to be something that would only occur in a writer's imagination, and the ending to be pointlessly cute.Again, the opening scenes of the dawning awareness that a child has been abducted are powerful, but the film totally lost me with its comic book sensationalism, sadism, and - I have to say it - stupidity.
summary: Fine Performances, Evocative Direction, Screwball Script

Given my own seven-decade experience of racism in America in New England, in the South, in the Midwest, and in the Northwest, I found this incredible as a story premise.HERE BE A FEW SPOILERS - The first two of four prisoners referred to by the title are the two young daughters of Jackman and Howard (one white; one black) who within a very short time are kidnapped in broad daylight. (Later, two adults are held as prisoners by people NOT associated with the police.) Within minutes of the kidnapping, however, a super detective (played by Jake Gyllenhaal) apprehends a suspect, a retarded young man (Paul Dano), who seems to have been living with his elderly aunt, but (apparently) the police have the wrong man in custody and have to release him. This does NOT sit well with Hugh Jackman's macho, take-charge self-image: he decides to do some "enhanced interrogation" of his own, with the very reluctant help of his beloved black buddy (Terrence Howard). Prolonged GRAPHIC TORTURE SCENES ensue.HERE BE A FEW MORE SPOILERS - Meanwhile Det. Gyllenhaal, who has never taken on a case without solving it, begins to suspect that a SERIAL KILLER is involved and tracks down an alternative suspect who has more than a few screws loose ... and while engaged in his own "enhanced interrogation," Det. G. goofs up and brings about the death of that new suspect.BUT WAIT, IT GETS WILDER - Just when there seems to be a dead end, as LUCK would have it, the little black girl CONVENIENTLY is able to escape her captor and reunite with her family! And somehow she puts Hugh Jackman on to a new trail ... which has a very bad outcome for him - besides him being shot. (At this point the audience knows for certain WHO the perverted serial killer is - and that "answer" is LITERALLY unbelievable.)But of course there is MORE to come. Det. Gyllenhaal also discovers who that pervert is, and he too is shot (in the head) but keeps on ticking and SAVES not one but TWO prisoners of the pervert ... but not (tweet) at the same time (tweet).The audience (tweet) expects Det. Gyllenhaal (who has NOT been suspended for causing the death of a suspect in custody and who immediately is released from the hospital and NOT kept under observation) to achieve some sort of additional unbelievable SUCCESS despite his head wound (tweet), and he (tweet) does so ... in exactly the (tweet) way that any eight-year-old who is halfway paying attention to this film will (tweet) easily (tweet) guess fifteen minutes before it (tweet, tweet) ends.If I were giving this film a letter grade, in my judgment it deserves a "D-". A very good cast is almost TOTALLY WASTED here.

reviewText: The stuff that separates a good film from a great film can be so elusive. "Gone Baby Gone" is a kidnap based plot and it's one of my favorites. But seeing "Prisoners" put the entire genre in a whole new realm.Here's the scoop. Set in rural Pennsylvania, two families are celebrating Thanksgiving when their two youngest daughters go missing. The police are called and the investigation begins. But the one father, Keller Dover (Hugh Jackman) has his own ideas of what happened and pursues his own line of investigation. Both his work and that of the detective Loki (Jake Gyllenhaal) take some surprising turns.It's difficult to express how incredibly good this film is. Famed d.p. Roger Deakins lensed it and keeps the sheen off. This does not have the gloss of a Hollywood production. This is middle class America and you feel as though you are there with these people. The mud, rain, snow and budget furniture are things most of us have experienced. And the relationship between Gyllenhaal and his Captain is peculiar to say the least. Let's look at Gyllenhaal's Loki. First, he's named after the Norse God. He's great at what he does, But this is no slick, college educated guy. He looks as though he came up from the street. He's got a big tattoo on his neck. Others on his hands and knuckles (I'd love to know what those symbols represent). His clothes don't fit well and he seems to have no family or close friends. What an interesting character. And Hugh Jackman. I'm not a big fan of his because I just don't think he's that good, but he does a real stand-up job here. Far better than I've ever seen him. Same with Terrence Howard. This, for my dollar, is his best work. But Maria Bello, Paul Dano, Viola Davis, Melissa Leo all turn in great performances.What really shines here is the script. You think you have things nailed down but it keeps twisting up to the end. And these aren't cheap plot turns. Though at first you might be scratching your head, all the loose ends come together in a very realistic fashion. The hand of God does come down in one crucial scene and part of the climax is a bit Hollywood but the rest is so outstanding it's easy to forgive it its weaknesses. And the ending. What a total creepfest.If you liked "Gone Baby Gone" or "Mystic River" this is a must see.

reviewText: Hugh Jackman continues to be a huge draw and a well-respected A-list actor in Hollywood.  Even though he earned his popularity as the comic book character, Wolverine, in the X-Men films, it would appear his comic book drawing power isn't what it used to be.  Jackman's most recent film, The Wolverine, was a bit of a disappointment and prompted questions about whether or not his tenure of playing the character might be coming to an end in the not so distant future.  While this might disappoint comic book fans, it might not be the worst news since Jackman continues to thrive in dramatic roles.  Within the last year alone, Jackman has been nominated for an Academy Award and won a Golden Globe for Best Actor in a Musical or Comedy for his portrayal of Jean Valjean in Les Misérables.  Now, Hugh Jackman is back in a dramatic role once again for the mystery thriller, Prisoners.Directed by Denis Villeneuve (Incendies), Prisoners stars Hugh Jackman as Keller Dover, a parent that is severely distraught after the sudden disappearance of his young daughter, Anna (Erin Gerasimovich) and her friend, Joy (Kyla Drew Simmons).  The local police quickly become involved as Detective Loki (Jake Gyllenhaal), a detective that has yet to leave a case unresolved, quickly targets Alex Jones (Paul Dano), as the potential kidnapper, despite a lack of evidence.  Regardless of the fact that Jones is a mentally challenged man and appears to be innocent, Keller decides to kidnap him and torture him anyway, believing he's the one holding the girls.  As the days pass and time continues to run out, Loki focuses on a variety of different possible suspects, all the while Dover and Joy's father, Franklin (Terrence Howard), continue their abusive attempts to make Jones reveal the whereabouts of the girls.  Viola Davis, Maria Bello, and David Dastmalchian also star in supporting roles.First and foremost - as far as the story goes, Prisoners is an enjoyable thrill-ride from start to finish.  At no point does this story ever feel slow or lack entertainment value.  There is enough happening within this story that it will keep you guessing about which one of the characters is guilty, all the while wondering to what the extent the main characters will go to find out where their daughters are being held.  However, there is a bit too much story than there really needs to be - often spending too much time introducing new characters with no other purpose than to throw viewers off about whom the real guilty party turns out to be.  Naturally, the introduction of these characters causes the plot to balloon out to the point that the film might have some moviegoers checking their watch.  But, if the biggest complaint is about the movie being 15 minutes too long, that's usually a good sign for the overall quality of the flick.Co-starring alongside Hugh Jackman is another Academy Award nominee, Jake Gyllenhaal.  Playing a relentless detective, Gyllenhaal most certainly shines in this role, although no more or less than in his most recent endeavors, such as End of Watch, Love & Other Drugs, and Zodiac.  Gyllenhaal has become a household name himself and although his scenes are not as emotionally involved as Jackman's scenes, he still gives a standout performance.  His slicked-back hair, nervous ticks, and tattoos depict him to be a hard-nosed, overzealous law enforcer that pushes the laws to the limit to retrieve vital information. In one particular scene, his character goes nose-to-nose with one of the potential kidnappers, which eventually ends with a needlessly bloody outcome - due to his character's lack of patience.  Clearly, Detective Loki (which feels like an Avengers plug) is the type of detective any parent would want on the street looking for their missing child.While Jake Gyllenhaal is just as much of a main player as Hugh Jackman, he is easily outshined by Jackman's role of the emotionally distraught father.  It's unimaginable how it must feel to have you child kidnapped, but Jackman does a commanding job in the role as he goes through the periods of being fearful, angry, and eventually vengeful - nearly to the fullest extent.  He presses the relevant question, how far would you go as a father to find your kidnapped child?  The emotions flowing through Jackman's character makes for some extremely intense scenes, including a film scene-stealing in which Jackman's character faces off with Gyllenhaal's character outside a liquor store.  Even though Jackman's portrayal is absolutely flawless throughout the course of this mystery flick, this particular scene is a prime example of what drives people to go to movies in the first place.  This is dramatic acting at its absolutely finest.The supporting cast of Prisoners follows the coattails of Jackman and Gyllenhaal closely.  The portrayals by Paul Dano as suspected kidnapper Alex Jones and Terrence Howard as parent Franklin Birch are both noteworthy, but are easily overshadowed and play second fiddle to A-list stars, not to mention the film's captivating storyline - written by Aaron Guzikowski.  Each interaction between the film's characters is better than the last as the film progresses, and as the scenes become tenser, it becomes abundantly clear that Guzikowski's feel for these characters is spot-on.  The writing and dialogue are obviously one of the main contributing factors in the overall success of this film.Overall, Prisoners is gripping, mysterious, and a complete joy to witness, regardless of its traumatic nature.  Hugh Jackman gives the performance of a lifetime, and while it's difficult to say it's the best role of his career, it certainly includes one particular scene that will go down as one of his all-time most memorable moments.  Honestly, there isn't enough praise for the cast of this film, but it really is the plot that makes this such a unique and ambitious film.  And, the best part of this film is the end.  If you think you can see this film's outcome long before it happens, you'll be dead wrong.  You may guess who the "bad guy" turns out to be, but the last scene is completely unpredictable.  While the film might not have the most desirable ending for some, it absolutely has the proper ending.  Prisoners should quickly be added to the top of every must-see movie list and is easily one of the most recommended films of the year.  Enjoy.GRADE:  A-FNDNreview.com
summary: 'Prisoners' the must-see mystery thriller of the year

reviewText: I was looking forward to the movie based on the normal quality of the work by such actors as Jackman but....I assume that the director was adhering to the written screenplay but that was actually the poor choice in the movie's rendition.Normally, if there can ever be a "normality" associated with such a terrible event as a child abduction, the decent into the hell of panic, frustration and hate/revenge by the parents (Jackman, et. al.), would help to raise the clarity of the characters and their own failings and foibles. Not so in this case. Additionally, the characterization of the detective does not "normally" exacerbate the spiraling of the parents.In this case, the writer decided to provide the audience with what I would characterize as "snippets" rather than a cohesive flow. These "snippets" may help pander to the grisliness of the "reflective abduction and torture" of the supposed child abductor and help to hold the audience in a tension centered around the choices we might make between what is right and wrong. However, it was at this point that the movie became tedious because once the characters were in this horrific dilemma the piece goes from "searching" to "revenge" to "sadism" in quick order.Fortunately for writers in hollywood, they can merely construct a way out of the contrived dilemma by making the decision to wreak revenge, the actual right/wrong/right decision flow. This construct then leaves the movie with some needed way to reflect the ultimate karma on Jackman's character by placing him in a "hole" - literally! Moreover, the audience is then left hanging at the end of the movie with the detective looking wistfully into the night wondering why he is hearing a whistle at which time the screen goes to final credits.Way too tedious (centering on the questions of right and wrong), and way too glib (centering on the "superman" capabilities of the abductors and the "foolishness/bumbling" of the everyman parents and detective). The movie production values cast by the dreariness of the Pennsylvania winter-scape does place a "nice" pall on the movie throughout, by-the-way. Having spent many a winter in Pennsylvania I can attest to the dreariness!Child abductions will always be horrific and affected parents will always attempt anything they can in order to find their children but to make them "mock" revengers does a disservice to the real men and women who attempt to rectify real child abduction situations, in my opinion.I finished the movie wondering why Jackman and the rest of the cast allowed themselves to be associated with the screenplay but I suppose money does the talking.

reviewText: Director Denis Villeneuve shocked us with his masterful `Incendies' and he does it again with this intensely suspenseful highly polished drama PRISONERS written by Aaron Guzikowski. Though the film is quite long (153 minutes) the tension is sustained making the viewer not so much an observer but a member of this funky little cold town where so much evil happens.The time is the present (the location shooting was Georgia but any small town across the country could well substitute), it is Thanksgiving and two close families are gathered in their neighborhood for the feast; the Dovers - father Keller (Hugh Jackman, mother Grace (Maria Bello), daughter Anna (Erin Gerasimovich) and son Ralph (Dylan Minnette) and the Birches - father Franklin (Terrence Howard), mother Nancy (Viola Davis), daughters Eliza (Zoe Borde) and Joy (Kyla Drew Simmons). Joy and Anna disappear and panic strikes. The only lead is a dilapidated RV that had earlier been parked on their street. Heading the investigation, Detective Loki (Jake Gyllenhaal) arrests its driver, Alex Jones (Paul Dano), but a lack of evidence forces his release. As the police pursue multiple leads and pressure mounts, knowing his child's life is at stake the frantic Keller Dover decides he has no choice but to take matters into his own hands. His methods involve capturing and torturing Alex with Franklin's help, but neither is sure of the outcome of their interrogation. Twists and turns occur involving a drunken sicko priest (Len Cariou) and the aunt/mother of Alex (Melissa Leo) - both leading to very surprising endings.The cast is as first rate as they come. Everyone is strong by Hugh Jackman and Jake Gyllenhaal are brilliant. Viola Davis, Melissa Leo, and Maria Bello involve with their usual excellent acting abilities. But in the end credit must go to director Denis Villeneuve for his superb sculpting of this terrifying film. Highly recommended. Grady Harp, December 13

reviewText: I saw this on the recommendation of a friend/co-worker.  While the climax of the movie seems a bit forced, and the attempt by the filmmakers to make the plot like the labyrinth that holds the key to the kidnapped girls' location begins to get a bit tiresome, what sticks with me are the performances. Paul Dano, who first caught my attention for his brilliance in "There Will Be Blood," is pitiable as the mentally challenged young man who seems like the prime suspect.  His torture as the hands of Jackman's character happens mostly off-screen (thankfully), but he remains a sad, lost, sympathetic figure even when he's clearly hiding something.  My favorite performance, though, is Jake Gyllenhaal as the taciturn Det. Loki.  The "defective detective" has become a cliché in modern procedural drama, but what makes Loki an intriguing character are the qualities only hinted at: the tattoos, the nerdy/hipster clothes and hair, the Freemasons ring, the involuntary blinking especially when stressed.  These all hint at a dark past that is never dragged into the spotlight and add to the character's mystery.  When Loki finally explodes, it's as if he's releasing everything he's repressed since before the events of this movie.  Brilliant acting and super backstory building by Gyllanhaal, who has impressed me since "Donnie Darko."Unfortunately, other terrific actors get short shrift due to the trio of outstanding performances already mentioned.  Terrance Howard in particular is tragically underserved in his role as Jackman's friend and attempted voice of consciousness. reviewText: Sacrifice is a common theme in Prisoners from the opening scene in the forest Keller Dover (Hugh Jackman) recites a prayer while his son Ralph Dover (Dylan Minnette) kills his first deer to the climax where the kidnapper explains that god is the reason why he or she is doing what they are doing and the reasoning behind all the violence her or she has committed, and it both benefits and hurts Prisoners making it a gripping yet an overly long and flawed mystery thriller.As with any good mystery thriller there has to be tension to keep the viewer guessing what will happen next, and suspense as to keep the viewer guessing as whom the murderer is, but first we must take a step back. Keller Dover is down on his luck carpenter whom is struggling, but still able to provide for his family. Keller a deeply spiritual man and his family head to his friend Franklin Birch (Terrence Howard) home for Thanksgiving. The two families eat, drink and have fun until their daughters Anna Dover (Erin Gerasimovich) and Joy Birch (Kyla Drew Simmons) head off on their own, and never return to the Birch's home. With the tension rising as the parents call the police and search the neighborhood for the strange RV Ralph had spotted earlier, and this is where Detective Loki (Jake Gyllenhaal) makes his appearance when he gets the call about the RV arresting Alex Jones (Paul Dano).The tension and suspense really ratchets up in Prisoners from this point on as Loki and the CSI's find no evidence that Alex took the two girls, and is forced to let Alex go free yet Keller after a confrontation with Alex is sure the man knows where his daughter is and takes matters into his own hand. Director Denis Villeneuve and writer Aaron Guzikowski do a good job keeping up the drama and suspense as they keep hinting that Alex might be the kidnapper yet at the same time throwing in more suspects along the way to keep the viewer guessing until close to the end of the film. Besides the theme of sacrifice another theme Villeneuve and Guzikowski throw in a moral one as well, and try to get the viewer to understand Keller's decisions he has made like how far would you go to find your daughter, what sacrifices would you make to find your daughter, and for the majority of the film director Villeneuve and writer Guzikowiski succeed in doing so.While I really enjoyed Prisoners I had some issues with the story, and the characters as well with the biggest issue being the climax of the film. You wanted to see if the parents were worth of god's love? I know I can't read the minds of serial killers and kidnappers, but the reasoning just didn't match the tone of the film, and where the story was headed. I expected a better thought out payoff than the one I got in Prisoners. Along with the reasoning behind the kidnapping leads to another issue I had with the final act of Prisoners in that the kidnapper could have easily gotten away with it if he or she had just answered the door for Loki. They had plenty of time to hide the evidence, and Loki had no reason or a warrant to search the home. That scene just took me out of what was supposed to be a tension filled scene. Finally there is the scene with Grace Dover (Maria Bello) and detective Loki where she explains that everything her husband did was justified and without him doing what he did Loki wouldn't have found their daughter, which is just crap. I can't believe the writers trying to justify what Keller did forced the character Grace to say that, and I know she's Keller's wife, but Grace can't honestly believe that even if she won't voice it out loud. It was simply laughable moment, because what Keller did was all for nothing. Nothing he did helped find his daughter in fact he was hindering the investigation as Loki had to look into the disappearance of Alex taking time away from searching for the missing children. Director Villeneuve and writer Guzikowiski nearly let everything they achieved in Prisoners fall apart in the final act with plot holes, poorly written dialogue, and out of character decisions made by certain characters. The other problem I had with the Prisoners was the length of the film. The film I watched didn't justify a length of two hours and a half. With some smart editing the film could have been cut down to around two hours and fifteen minutes, and I believe those cuts would have added to the tension and suspense of the film.While the final act of Prisoners faltered the performances by the actors didn't. Hugh Jackman gives his best performance since the Prestige if not his career as Keller. The emotion Jackman gives to Keller brings to life the character and the decisions he has made, and the price Keller has paid making theme. Jake Gyllenhaal also gives an outstanding performance as Detective Loki who has chosen the job over having a family. Gyllenhaal really should stay away from the blockbuster films like Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time and the Day After Tomorrow, because Gyllenhall is a far better actor in dramatic roles than action roles as he has proven in Donnie Darko, End of Watch, and Brokeback Mountain. Maria Bello doesn't have much to do in Prisoners as the distraught Grace Dover, but she gives a believable performance as a mother who has lost her daughter cutting herself off from the outside world. Like Mario Bello, Terrence Howard doesn't have much to do in his role as Franklin Birch as he is relegated to Keller's accomplice, but the experienced actor Howard gives his all in the role displaying the conflicting emotions when is morality is tested as he helps Keller in his quest to find their daughters.If not for the faulty final act, and climax Prisoners would go down as one of the great mystery thrillers like Memento, The Silence of the Lambs, and L.A. Confidential, but even with its flaws Prisoners is a riveting engrossing thriller with a quality moral story that will keep you guessing nearly to the end, outstanding performances by Hugh Jackman, Jake Gyllenhaal, and the rest of the cast that helps to turn Prisoners into enthralling, nerve-racking and thoughtful thriller, and one of the better films of the year.
summary: Prisoners is a masterful thriller that delves into the moral quandary of parents desperate to find their daughters.

reviewText: ***This review may contain spoilers***The movie "Prisoners" simply starts with two families, the Dovers and the Birches, in a nondescript, blue-collar town, sharing a Thanksgiving dinner.  Then the two youngest members of both families, Anna Dover (Erin Gerasimovich) and Joy Birch (Kyla Drew Simmons) go to play outside supposedly under Anna's older brother Ralph's supervision.  They get close to a next-door neighbor's RV, but quickly leave when a pair of ominous eyes stare at them from inside.  Soon after, both nine-year old girls are missing and apparently kidnapped.  Methodical, persistent Detective Loki (Jake Gyllenhaal), with a perfect case-solving record, strives to find out who abducted the children and why.  There are a few suspects, but the most prominent one is Alex Jones (Paul Dano), a child-like young man who lives with caretaker aunt Holly (Melissa Leo) and who is arrested after violently trying to flee Loki and the police in the same RV. So now it's simply a matter of getting Alex to confess to the crime and reveal where the two girls are - isn't it?Perhaps it's not so simple.  "Prisoners" spins an elaborate, deliberate, and intelligent mystery with its share of clues, red herrings, and frustrating dead ends.  But I believe the movie's primary focus IS reflected in its nuanced title and how the characters react to it.  Both families, including Grace Dover (Maria Bello), Franklin Birch (Terrence Howard), and Nancy Birch (Viola Davis) are understandably psychologically imprisoned by anxiety, suspense, tension, and horror at their loss - almost to the point of inertia.  However, Keller Dover (Hugh Jackman) is not so passive.  He is imprisoned by more than just fear; he seethes with vengeance and wrath.  He is not satisfied with what he sees as cursory treatment of primary suspect Alex by Loki and the police and is enraged by Alex's release from custody due to insufficient evidence.  Insufficient evidence, hell! Keller, a home renovator, has his own ways of making Alex talk...As the mystery progresses, "Prisoners" takes the time to explore Keller's struggle between justice and revenge and the viewer's attitude toward his actions.  As Keller retaliates with his own kidnapping and subsequent torture of Alex, I think many viewers will simultaneously sympathize with and be repelled by Keller's behavior.  If we lost a child, of course many of us would rage, and swear, and be spurred to some kind of action.  But would we do the things Keller does to Alex, things that begin to border on the sadistic?  As it winds toward the kidnapping resolution, the revelation of the culprit, Alex's fate, and, surprisingly, Keller's ironic fate,  "Prisoners" reminds us that no situation, even a kidnapping and possible torture, justifies letting ourselves being imprisoned by mindless and perhaps misguided vengeance.  In this regard, Detective Loki provides contrast.  Even though he gets violently frustrated by the case, Loki's professionalism and logic keep him on course and help him progress in his investigation.  Keller does not do the same for most of the movie until it's too late.  Like Loki, he learns the truth of the abduction, but his emotional prison may end up leading to a literal one as well.
summary: When It Comes to Holding "Prisoners", Emotions Can Be Stronger Than Iron Bars

reviewText: Every so often I see a movie that I can't get out of my head; a movie so fascinating, compelling and intricate and I can think of nothing else for days afterward. Prisoners is one such film. The movie focuses on two families whose daughters disappear on Thanksgiving day, and the subsequent search for them. Keller Dover (Hugh Jackman), the father of one of the little girls, takes matters into his own hands when the police fail to make any progress in the search. He becomes more and more rash and irrational, his methods more and more extreme. This is not Taken with Liam Neeson. This is a man who prepares for every situation and disaster, and loses it when he's faced with a crisis he never thought to prepare for. Hugh Jackman's Keller is frantic, angry and above all, desperate. His is a loud, red hot, full blooded performance that fully conveys the sense of anguish, rage, and fear that someone in his position would endure. The film asks the audience to consider how far is too far when it comes to your children's well-being. What would you do? Jake Gyllenhaal, in an interesting turn, plays the detective assigned to the case. Where Jackman's performance is showy (in a good way), Gyllenhaal turns in a layered, subtly nuanced performance. He is the long-suffering force that everyone in the film turns to for help, as well as to lay blame. But my favorite part of the movie is the cinematography. Its gorgeous. But either way, this is a thrilling and powerful piece of cinema. reviewText: PRISONERS, Denis Villeneuveis's gritty thriller about the kidnapping of two young girls in suburban Pennsylvania, is definitely compelling.  But it's also totally over-the-top and laden with ridiculous coincidences that defy credibility.  The screenplay, by Aaron Guzikowski (CONTRABAND), gives us a number of interesting characters, including harried police detective Loki (Jake Gyllenhaal), who is called in to investigate the disappearance of two girls on Thanksgiving Day.  The father of one of the girls, Keller Dover (Hugh Jackman), goes from being cooperative with the police to full-on vigilante after the prime suspect -- Alex Jones (Paul Dano), a disturbed young man whose RV was seen parked in the Dovers' neighborhood - is released for lack of evidence.  Dover's wife Grace (Maria Bello) spends most of the movie in a semi-catatonic state, waiting for word of her missing child.  And the other girl's parents, Franklin and Nancy Birch (Terrance Howard and Viola Davis), are little more than background characters.  So what we get is two-and-a-half hours of unrelenting tension as Loki tries to unravel the case and Dover goes abu ghraib on hapless Jones.  How far is it permissible to go to save a child?  And are we all prisoners, trapped by circumstances beyond our control into behaving in ways that destroy us?The biggest problem with the film, aside from its over-the-top sensationalism, is the number of coincidences that confound credibility.  [SPOILERS AHEAD -- proceed with caution!] Loki questions a priest who's on the sex offender list, and he finds a decomposed body in the basement.  Then there's a guy in a hoodie seen lurking around a candlelight vigil for the missing girls, and then later sneaking into their houses - turns out he's obsessed with mazes and has a thing for snakes and kids' clothes.  Loki also interviews the mother of a young boy who was kidnapped decades earlier under similar circumstances, a cute little boy seen riding his bike in videos.  Prime suspect Jones, who's described as having the IQ of a ten-year-old, lives with his aunt, whose husband disappeared five years before and hasn't been seen since.  All of these seemingly random events are ultimately connected like pieces in a jigsaw puzzle, fitting together to create an insidious picture of a world gone mad.  It's beyond soap opera, beyond anything that could pass for possible, and it undermines whatever impact the film ultimately delivers - or doesn't.There are definitely hints in PRISONERS of other films with similar themes, like THE VANISHING (1993), A SIMPLE PLAN (1998), IN THE BEDROOM (2001), and MYSTIC RIVER (2003).  In all of them, there are kidnappings, misunderstandings, vigilante actions, and twisted endings.  Innocent people die in these films, and ostensibly good people do very bad things.  The point of MYSTIC RIVER seems to be that when we play vigilante, even with the best of motives, we become the monsters we seek to destroy.  PRISONERS never goes quite that far, as if Guzikowski and Villeneuveis aren't quite willing to take a stand on the horror they splash across the screen.  Is Jackman's Keller Dover a monster of his own making, or just a father doing everything he can to find his missing daughter?  In other words, is he channeling Liam Neeson from TAKEN (2008), or Sean Penn from MYSTIC RIVER?  Because it makes a difference, and those are two very different film.I wish I had liked PRISONERS more, since it's one of the few films released this year that isn't about superheroes, comic books, or boob jokes.  For that reason alone, I hope it does well enough to encourage studios to continue producing adult films with intelligent scripts.  But I also wish the script were a bit more intelligent and a bit less sensational.  This isn't a bad film so much as a disappointing one.  With a cast like that it should have been amazing.  It isn't.  And that's a shame.  Watch it for the performances, for the bleak and unrelenting setting, and for the level of tension that never relents.  But be prepared for loose ends, over-the-top behavior (especially from Jackman's character), and enough coincidences to make the whole thing seem ultimately ridiculous.  It's worth talking about, though, and that's a good thing.  Not many movies are these days.
summary: Compelling thriller is over-the-top and ultimately ridiculous

reviewText: With zero expectations for this movie, it just blew me away on every level. I had only known it was some sort of revenge thriller involving a kidnapping. I honestly can't remember the last time I cared so much about a group of characters. From the outset, it's obvious that this is a serious and adult movie, one where nobody is safe, and a happy ending is hardly guaranteed after so many clever turns in the story. There is a darkness throughout even the heroes which can qualify the film as a neo-noir, despite its gloomy Northern country setting.There are many other superb elements to this movie beyond its engaging plot. The film looks absolutely amazing thanks to multi-Oscar-nominated cinematographer Roger Deakins, who's also shot Shawshank and a half-dozen of the Coen brothers' films. The score is perfectly simple but wonderful. The actors all give astoundingly heartfelt performances too.If you can handle this movie's intensity, it will haunt you with its elegance. This is one of the finest mystery/thrillers made of recent years due to the powerful heart which accompanies the heady procedural.

reviewText: Young parents Keller and Grace Dover walk over to the suburban home of Franklin and Nancy Birch in the November cold for a Thanksgiving Dinner involving neighbours, laughter and bad trumpet playing (Hugh Jackman, Maria Bello, Terence Howard and Viola Davis). Their respective daughters of 7 and 6 Anna and Eliza happily play upstairs with a pet while the adults below drink and reminisce. That is until both children go outside to play - and unaccompanied - addle up to the back of a muddied RV parked suspiciously by the kerb in broad daylight...Although I thoroughly despise material that uses children being hurt as entertainment - "Prisoners" beats the pants off so many supposed thrillers because it reeks of intelligence (a fantastic and clever script) and has a cast that emotionally rivets you to the screen every second they're up there. It's also prepared to be silent - ordinary even - thereby making some scenes disturbingly close to how real life actually is. It's unnerving, creepy and stomach churning in places too (there are monsters out there).In order for this to work you need major league actors - and lots of them - and right down to a repentant Paedophile Priest - even the small parts are perfectly cast. Hugh Jackman plays Keller Dover - a redecorator/builder and a 'prepare for the worst' deer-shooting survivalist - while his wife Grace believes she'll and her family will be 'safe' with him. Mild-mannered neighbours and friends Franklin and Nancy Birch have the opposite dynamic - the wife is the boss while her husband is more reflective.  But when a local simpleton Alex Jones is found singing in the front seat of the squalid RV and arrested but won't talk - both sets of parents have their patience and nerves tested. Frustrated by the cops lack of progress and working to the letter of the law - and with the days passing and time running out for their abducted daughters - Alpha Male Keller decides to take matters into his own hands...Into this emotional cauldron comes Detective Loki who's solved every case he's ever been given. He may at times seem too detached from the parent's pain and rage - but he's a man who spots things and sees through the lies in people (a mesmerizing Jake Gyllenhaal). Obsessive yet law-abiding - he instinctively feels that spaced out Alex Jones who can't say much but can still drive an RV easily - is lying - sickly concealing the whereabouts of the girls and enjoying the cat and mouse game too (an Oscar performance yet again from Paul Dano - the preacher in "There Will Be Blood"). But is he? And what about his heart-broken mother (subtle brilliance from Melissa Leo) who has defended this social outcast all her life - despite her religion-obsessed husband leaving years back and abandoning them both. Keller even goes after her. In the meantime Grace Dover (a ragged looking Maria Bello) simply breaks at the enormity of her child being lost - while the stoical Nancy folds her arms, grits her teeth and reconciles herself to what both fathers must do - go over demarcation lines you really shouldn't cross...The genius of Aaron Guzikowski's script and Dennis Villeneuve's Direction is that one whole hour in - and you're absolutely none the wiser as to who is the bad guy and who isn't. And it has to be said that some of the violence is horrible and cringing. But what keeps you watching is the sheer visceral power of the actors. The dance between Jackman and Gyllenhaal is fantastic cinema - both men barely holding on to any humanity or faith as the frustration mounts and suspicions arise (exactly the sick kind of mental torture the abductor wants to inflict on them). And you also sit there questioning just how far a determined parent would go to get their child back (abusing a man who may or may not be an innocent).Special mention has to be made of the picture quality of the BLU RAY. Defaulted to Full Aspect (which fills up the whole screen) - "Prisoners" is starkly gorgeous and truly beautiful throughout. Often without any music - the blunt and stainless steel cold angles ratchet up the tension to unbearable levels (fear of what is happening to the children). It's the Cinematography genius of ROGER DEAKINS ("The Shawshank Redemption" and "True Grit"). Scene after scene is filled with it: casing a house in the pouring rain at night - Jones walking his dog as Keller spies on him from a nearby truck - the decaying body tied to a chair in the basement of a suspect's house - Detective Loki interviewing a sex offender you can't see behind a filthy pane of glass - Loki's tired bulging eyes and unkempt stubble (hasn't slept for days) as he leans forward into a computer monitor scouring the screen for any detail that will help - closing in on the jagged bark of a tree... The framing of everything is the unsung hero of the movie - adding unbelievable depth and genuine unease that serves right up until the superb and clever ending.There are two Extras - the short "Every Moment Counts" and the more extensive "Powerful Performers" which features enthusiastic interviews with all the principal actors, Director Dennis Villeneuve and Producers Kara Davis and Broderick Johnson. But don't watch "Powerful Performers" before you watch the movie - it rather clumsily gives away far too much in terms of the twisting plot.The brilliant and unsettling "Prisoners" had my wife and I on the edge of our seats unable to press the pause button to desperately go to the loo. Now that's how you put the 'thrill' in thriller.Job done I'd say...

reviewText: Prisoners is a compelling drama/thriller about two families that are forced to deal with the loss of their young daughters. When the girls go missing over the course of a seemingly normal afternoon, multiple lives are thrown into chaos in the ensuing struggle not just to find the children but also to deal with the cold reality of a world where things like this usually only happen to other people.The plot of the movie is deceptively straightforward, but the performances and the underlying message of the film are so thickly layered that the film is a deeply engaging experience, in spite of the harsh, disturbing story it tells. This is probably the best acting I've ever seen from either Jackman or Gyllenhaal, not to mention the rest of the cast, including the remarkably talented Paul Dano as the movie's primary suspect in the kidnapping.For a movie that has so much going on under the surface, there's very little that can be said about it without marring the amazing depth and complexity that it sets up in so many of the characters. Suffice it to say that, by the film's final moment, the title seems to have half a dozen different interpretations, the movie less about what it takes to get justice or right wrongs than it is about the many ways people can find themselves trapped by their own hearts, minds, or actions. Although the movie doesn't have a lot of action in the traditional sense, there is a whole world of turmoil and energy boiling beneath the paper-thin layers of nearly every character, even when they're just sitting and staring into space.The best example of a movie that takes silence and stasis and turns into something that is nearly impossible to ignore, PRISONERS is one of the best dramas I've seen in a long time, and not the least because it makes absence and doubt into something so riveting and tumultuous.

reviewText: If you have children, or if you are attached to a niece or nephew, then PRISONERS will make you quake in your boots from start to finish. It takes the most terrifying idea that a parent has, your child being abducted, and tosses it about in a fashion unseen before on screen. Is that a good thing? Yes.The film opens with two families living in the same neighborhood getting together for Thanksgiving. One is Keller and Grace Dover (Hugh Jackman and Maria Bello), the other Franklin and Nancy Birch (Terence Howard and Viola Davis). After dinner the Dover's daughter wants to run home with the Birch's daughter to look for a whistle she can't find. Terror soon follows.The two girls can't be found and the older kids they were supposed to ask go with them never knew that they left. From an earlier walk Dover's son remembered an RV parked down the road that his sister tried to climb. A manhunt follows with everyone searching for the girls and that RV.As it so happens Detective Loki (Jake Gyllenhall) gets the call about a sighting of the RV. He gets to the scene only to have the driver speed into a tree and then be captured. What they find is a young man named Alex Jones (Paul Dano) with some mental issues who either can't or won't answer their questions. Keller can't believe the police are as helpless as he is when it comes to finding answers and holds them accountable.The search continues and eventually Jones is released. Keller confronts him in the parking lot and Jones whispers something to him that makes Keller believe he knows what happened to the girls. Intent on finding his daughter, even if the police have their hands tied with legalities, Keller kidnaps Jones and takes him to an abandoned apartment building he owns. With the reluctant help of Franklin he systematically tortures Jones to get information. It's brutal but not over done considering what's on the screen these days.As Keller seeks information his way Det. Loki follows clues of his own. With a record of solving every case he's been assigned he doggedly pursues each lead that comes his way. Some go nowhere but a few turn up a suspect other than Jones, one who turns up at a candle light vigil for the two girls and who escapes Loki when he pursues him on foot. This doesn't stop him from continuing his search as well as his looking at Keller as a possible suspect as well.Do they find the girls? Are they still alive? And just who really kidnapped them if anyone? If you want to know what happens rent or buy the movie, don't expect me to give it away. The twists and turns in this plot bounce back and forth more than Mullholland Drive if it were ice covered and foggy. The movie does a great job of making you think one way then convincing you that you should look another only to toss in a third concept before making you think you were right to begin with. Got that? Well that's the sort of back and forth I'm talking about. In the end everything fits in place and the result is an ending that makes sense. I won't say you'll be happy with it, but it makes sense.As seems to be the case with many films these days there isn't a bad performance on screen here. Jackman and Gyllenhall take center stage when it comes to outstanding performances, both exercising their acting muscles by playing parts different than we've seen them in before. Howard is given far too small a part to play here but does it well. Bello and Davis feel more like supporting roles than leads here and that's a shame. Dano once more plays that misunderstood character and does a fine job.Don't let the 153 minute length scare you away. Time flies when you're watching this one and there isn't a boring moment. And when you get to the last 30-40 minutes you'll be wringing your hands waiting to see what happens next. This one is worth watching.
