reviewText: Director: Denis Villeneuve.Writer: Aaron Guzikowski.Staring: Hugh Jackman, Jake Gyllenhaal, Paul Dano, Viola Davis, Terrence Howard, Maria Bello, Melissa Leo and David Dastmalchian.Running Time: 153 minutes.Rating: R for Disturbing Violent Content including Torture, and Language throughout.Let's get this right out of the way for Prisoners: It is not a happy a movie. If you're expecting a good time or to come out with a smile on your face, this is not your type of movie. You would be much better off popping in something like Pacific Rim or seeing if Frozen is still playing where you live. But even if a film is horribly depressing, that doesn't mean you shouldn't watch it if given the chance. Far from it with something like Prisoners, the English language debut of Canadian director Denis Villeneuve (Incendies). While its grueling content and odd plot points may cause some contention with viewers, Prisoners delivers on damn near every cylinder you should expect to see in a good mystery: Excellent performances, a plot that keeps you guessing till the very end, haunting cinematography and some interesting debates on morality and what one would do and how far they would go to save a loved one.One day, somewhere in Pennsylvania, a small get together with two families is going on. Set sometime around Thanksgiving, the two families The Dovers (Hugh Jackman playing Keller and Maria Bello playing Grace) and The Birches (Viola Davis playing Nacy and Terrence Howard playing Franklin) are having a nice get together. Everybody's laughing, chowing down tasty food, just having a good time together. The teens hang out while the youngsters, Anna Dover and Joy Birch, are off playing around in the neighborhood.A few hours latter, the two youngest disappear. An investigation is soon kicked into motion and headed by Detective Loki (Jake Gyllenhaal) to find out who it is Eventually, the find a suspect in the form of mentally handicapped Alex Jones (Paul Dano). But due to the fact there is a lack of evidence on whether he did it or not, he winds up being released. The father of one of the families, Keller Dover, however, becomes increasingly unstable over the course of the investigation, resorting to his own (brutal) methods to find out if Alex actually did it or not.So yes, as one can tell from that synopsis up top, Prisoners isn't what one would call a "feel good movie". On top of that, it isn't one that goes by quick. It fully expects you to sit down and watch as it takes you on a long journey of what its like to have a child taken from you. Whether you have or haven't had kids, you feel steeped in the misery and horror of what the parents go through in the film. Hell, the film was originally slapped with an NC-17 rating before it got re-edited with a R. Frankly, after watching the film itself, it doesn't surprise me that it almost got the former.Another interesting note to make is that in addition to being a Drama-Mystery-Thriller, the film is also a play on morality. Most of the characters never stay clean for long, especially High Jackman's character, who pulls some especially dickish things to find his kid. As seen in the trailers (don't worry; this all happens in the first half hour), he winds up kidnapping Alex to find out where the children are, but what he does will make your stomach churn. Even as the film went as on, I found myself conflicted with his character, wanting him to find his kids but I wished he'd stop being such an ass in trying to find his kid. The film itself and its characters are even asking themselves if what they're doing is justified or not.What I found interesting about the film is that you never really know who's who or what till the end. For the majority of the film's running time, it keeps you guessing on whether Alex did it or not. Is he playing stupid? Does he genuinely not know what happened to the kids? Was he manipulated into doing what he did? It's like being in a maze, a nightmarish labyrinth from where there is no escape from until the very end.The film's performances are uniformly excellent, with Hugh Jackman showing us a scary side of his acting abilities that we haven't seen before. His character shows a broad range of anger, ruthlessness and regret. The performance as Dover is so good, it outright makes his iconic Wolverine role look downright pathetic by comparison. I can also safely say that thanks to this role, Jackman's was able to partially redeem himself after being in last year's blunderpiece Movie 43. He's not quite there yet, but I hold him in much higher regard than I did after 43. The rest of the supporting cast also give great performances as well. Jake Gyllenhaal continues to be one of the best actors working today, with an almost equally compelling side role as the determined Detective Loki. One scene in particular that stands out for me with him is when flips out in his office. I won't say what happens in regards to that part in what triggers him, but damn, he really lost it in a big way.Terrence Howard and Paul Dano bring their goods to the table as well, as does Maria Bello and Viola Davis. Melissa Leo also shows up as Alex Jones' mother, Holly, and while she doesn't have that many scenes in the film, she is compelling enough to keep an admirable presence on-screen. Even the kids who play Joy and Anna (Kyla Drew Simmons and Erin Gerasimovich, respectively) do their roles without some kind of saccharine or sickly-sweet kind of way that one would usually expect from kids in movies.Shot by famous cinematographer Roger Deakins (Skyfall, No Country For Old Men, The Shawshank Redemption), Prisoners looks unsurprisingly beautiful in its imagery. Damn near every frame looks downright perfect, with scenes that look like they were molded by a paint brush than a camera. Denis and Deakins obviously know what they're doing, and I hope that they collaborate more in the future. Then there's the score by Jóhann Jóhannsson, who achieves haunting yet minimalist work that help establish the mood of the picture quite excellently.If there were any problems I had with the film, I'd say it would be some plot elements. There's something that happens to Paul Dano's character in which he ends up disappearing from the public eye and it doesn't really get addressed until the last 30 minutes of the movie. Arguably, due to the investigation of the girls, I can see how their disappearance could be held in higher regard than Dano's but it was still a little something that bothered me.Then there's how the film handles its clues, foreshadowing and red-herrings, in which it maybe just a little too clever for its own good. It's great to see a film keep its audience guessing all the way through and then pull the rug under their feet when they least expect it, but it felt like the movie was getting a little overly complicated. Not that it was a major hindrance to the film's quality, but I can see how some would be fed up with the plot twists and the loopty loops the film pulls from time to time.It's a shame that the film was missed at the Oscar season. It was a big contender in the first couple of weeks it came out but due to being swarmed by a mountain of other films (Gravity, 12 Years A Slave, The Wolf of Wall Street), it sadly got overlooked and wound up with only a nom for Best Cinematography. Yet, in spite of that, its more than worth checking out. Its imagery, performances and plot won't leave you for a while and it will keep you engaged all the way through its long running time.

reviewText: Prisoners is yet another installment in the crime/abduction movie genre starring Hugh Jackman and Jake Gyllenhaal.  Prisoners is not really my type of movie.  I’m not generally into crime dramas whether it be crime/abduction movies or the few dozen crime dramas on television like CSI, Criminal Minds, NCIS, Law and Order, etc.  I would not have seen this film had it not have starred Hugh Jackman or Jake Gyllenhaal.I am a big fan of Hugh Jackman. I thought he was good in the Day After Tomorrow and I thought he was great in Zodiac.  Without these two this movie would not have been as good.  They were both amazing in this film.I knew the film would at least be decent because those two actors were in it and the film is getting pretty good reviews so far on Rotten Tomatoes.  I saw the film and I liked it.  I will say that out of all the crime drama films that I have seen I would that this is one of the better ones.  It is well acted by everyone in the cast, not just by Jackman and Gyllenhaal.  The story was also good and fairly well executed.  I will also admit that this film does something a little bit different than most crime dramas that I have seen.The story is fairly simple.  It is very much like it was advertised in the trailers.  You have two families.  One family consists of a man named Keller Dover (Hugh Jackman), his wife Gracie Dover (Maria Bello), his son Ralph, and his daughter Anna.  The other family consists of a man named Franklin (Terrence Howard), his wife Nancy (Viola Davis), his eldest daughter Eliza, and the youngest daughter Joy.  The two children, Anna and Joy, end up being abducted by an unknown individual.  An investigator named Loki (Jake Gyllenhaal) to investigate the case.  They have the primary suspect named Alex in custody.  However, they cannot find anything on him and release him.  Dover obsessed with getting his daughter back and takes the law into his own hands.The movie is very good, but it is not a movie that can be watched casually.  It is very depressing and does not end the best.  The characters do some pretty messed up things that make you like them less, but you do see where they are coming from. To be honest that is really the only way this movie could have ended though.  I usually prefer triumphant endings, but this one could not really end happily.  From what occurs in the movie and certain actions the main character takes, if the film ended happily it would have felt like a cop out.Overall, Prisoners is a well-done crime drama.  I will say that this, Zodiac, and The Dark Knight (yes I count it as a crime drama) are my favorite films in this particular genre.  It is well-acted well plotted and well executed.  If you like crime dramas then give this a look.

reviewText: Theatrical Review.  There may be spoilers.Director Denis Villeneuve ("Incendies") asks the question, "What would you do if your child disappears?"  Hugh Jackman takes his Wolverine and Jean Valjean character's anger to a new level in this horrifying film.  He plays Keller Dover, a middle class Pennsylvanian who does work renovating houses.  His wife, Grace (Maria Bello) is a perfect companion.  Together they have 2 children.  Six year old Anna and teenage Ralph (Dylan Minnette).  They are having dinner at their neighbor and best friend's house.  Viola Davis and Terrence Howard are Nancy and Franklin Birch who have similar aged kids.  Young Eliza and teen daughter, Joy (Kyla Drew Simmons).After dinner, the two younger kids want to go back to the Dover house to retrieve a doll or something.  Nobody's paying much attention until everyone realizes they never came back.  The search is on and after checking the neighborhood, the police are called.  Jake Gyllenhaal plays Detective Loki who heads up the search.  The police quickly track down a suspect who had been mysteriously parked in front of a vacant house in the neighborhood.  Alex Jones (Paul Dano) is the prime suspect, but he isn't talking.  Primarily because he has the mind of a 10 year old.  In addition, his RV that the girls had been playing on earlier, produced no evidence that the girls were ever there.The two families, Keller in particular, are convinced that Jones knows where the girls are and are frustrated that he is released by the police.  As days past, Loki follows other clues while still focusing on Jones.  This doesn't satisfy Keller who eventually takes matters into his own hands and kidnaps Jones, holding him captive in an old apartment building he owns.  Villeneuve doesn't hold back as Keller beats Jones to a bloody pulp, later moving him to a small closet for some old fashion water torture.  While all this is going on, Loki finds another suspect unbeknownst to Keller.  So is Jones innocent after all?Melissa Leo plays Holly Jones, Alex's adoptive aunt.  She's critical to the investigation, providing background to Alex's upbringing.  Her own background is a bit of a mystery, but both Loki and Keller continue to probe.  This movie is difficult to watch, not only because of the subject matter and torture scenes, but because it makes the viewer realize that there is an inner animal in all of us.  The writing is excellent, the cinematography is superb.  Strong performances by all but especially Jackman as Keller and Davis in her supporting role.  Dark and foreboding but a strong piece of filmmaking that will keep you talking well after the final credits roll.
summary: 4 1/2 stars:  Dark and foreboding but a strong piece of filmmaking

The sound, however, is a different story. There were moments of complete silence in the movie where the silence itself was a sound effect. There were intense moments that were accented by incredibly clear and poignant sound that fit the scene.Plot, oh boy was there plot! A great, edge of the seat, thrilling plot that just smacked me in the face every couple of minutes! The movie goes on for about 2.5 hours and the whole time I was glued to the screen. What an incredible story!********WARNING: HUGE SPOILERS BELOW, don't read any further unless you have seen the movie or for some reason just want to destroy the experience of watching this film for yourself.*******************************************************************************************************************Ok, just so we are all on the same page, I am going to go through the plot and piece things together since there seems to be a bit of confusion on Who Bobby Taylor was, how joy escaped, and what the Leo's were actually doing to children.We start off being introduced to Keller Dover and his son , Ralph. Keller recites the Lord's Prayer and his son lines up a shot for a deer. This scene is blatantly metaphorical for "doing what is necessary" in Keller's perspective. It also shows how Ralph is becoming a man. This plays well against Alex Jones because it shows you what Alex never had and why he isn't a "man" but rather still a 10 year old boy. (Obviously abuse and drugs/snake venom had something to do with it too). This is how Keller works, he doesn't enjoy killing the deer but it is necessary to him and the ends justify the means. The prayer shows us that he doesn't "shoot the deer" for his own enjoyment, it is a means by which he can get what he needs for his family. This foreshadows the exact sentiment felt when he tortures Alex.We can now skip ahead to the children disappearing. We meet Detective Loki. He has tattoos but he hides them constantly. He clasps his hands to hide his knuckle tattoos and he buttons his shirt to the top button to hide his neck tattoos. He wears a masonic ring, His tattoos and his opening lines indicate that he has an interest in Zodiac signs and astrology- all information we are given throughout the film indicates that he had a rough past and was possibly a criminal turned cop. Loki is a prisoner of his past.Keller becomes a prisoner to his desperation, doing things he would never have done under normal circumstances, likewise his wife becomes a prisoner to her medication as a way of dealing with the tragedy of losing her daughter. Ralph becomes a prisoner of the house, his father the jailor. He is told to watch over his mother and stay home. Alex becomes Keller's prisoner in a very literal sense.  The children are obviously prisoners- I could go on. Everyone in the movie is a prisoner to something by this point.The RV is gone over CSI-Miami style and nothing is found- this is because Alex merely let the kids in, let them play and sing while he drove them to his "aunt's" house. This is what he meant when he said "They didn't cry until I left them." It also explains Ms. Leo's later comment that he only played with the children. Loki continues tracking down leads by visiting local sex offenders and happens upon a body in the creepy as f*** basement/crawl-space/nightmare-dungeon under the Priest's house. This body is wearing a necklace with a  circular maze etched on it, hmmmmm. It is also explained that the man has kidnapped and killed at least 16 children. This man is Ms. Leo's husband that she said disappeared after a fight. He is also the "invisible man" that the book in Bobby Taylor's house is about.Speaking of Bobby Taylor, aka "The Snake Guy," he was a former abductee, taken by the Leo's when he was  just a boy. He escaped somehow, it isn't ever explained, but he is now damaged and seeks to recreate the efforts of his captors to try and understand their motives. He is obsessed with it, going as far as stealing abducted children's clothes, spattering them with pigs blood and claiming to have killed them. He buries child-manikins in his yard after bashing in their heads. He is a mixture of a victim with Stockholm syndrome, a child, and a copycat killer. He too, is a prisoner to his past, he even goes so far as to wear the same jacket as Ms. Leo does (more on that later).So the Leo's have had a process that is now continued only by Ms. Leo since Mr. Leo is dead. By the end of the movie, we should be able to conclude that The Leo's had a son who died of cancer. They were religious prior to this and afterward, unable to reconcile the tragedy with their religion, they reject their religion and begin to "wage war on god" by abducting other people's children, creating "demons" aka the broken, parents of the abducted children. They do this alone at first and later by having Alex find and pick up children. The children are then delivered to the Leo's house where they are given Kool-Aid laced with ketamine and LCD and told that they can leave when they have solved a book fool of mazes. The catch is, the last maze, the same one that Mr. Leo wore around his neck, is unsolvable. Eventually the children are injected with snake venom and buried. This is exactly what happened to Joy and Anna but Joy was able to get away before she was injected. (Some might argue that there is a different order to it but this is the gist. All these things happen, it may be done in a different order depending on the kid)How did Joy get away? The movie tells you but it is a bit difficult to piece it together. We see Joy's flash backs when she is in the hospital room and it shows a person wearing a jacket carrying Anna in the right arm and reaching for Joy (who is running away) with her left. It also shows two bottles of the laced Kool-Aid, one full and one half empty. We can deduce that it was Ms. Leo in the Jacket, and that Joy did not drink her Kool-Aid. This fits with what Ms. Leo said about having to move the girls inside after Detective Loki was snooping around the car outside. Thus when Ms. Leo was moving them inside, Joy ran away and was picked up by a passing motorist.All this is pieced together when Keller visits Joy in the hospital and she says "You were there. She put tape on our mouths!" Keller thinks back and realizes the only place he has gone where there was a female suspect was the Leo's home. Joy must have heard his voice through the thin walls. He gains entry by half-heartedly pretending to offer assistance fixing up the house and ignores the obviously hidden weapon in her hand. This is the only part of the plot that made me cringe. We all knew she had a gun, and Keller should have too.So he gets drugged, shot,  and thrown in the pit- Loki finds Alex in Keller's old apartment building, in pretty bad shape assumingly. He is tasked with telling Ms. Leo they found Alex. Detective Loki lets himself in, finds Ms. Leo injecting Anna with venom and a firefight ensues, in which Loki gets grazed on the head and Ms. Leo gets gunned down. The scene where Loki drives Anna to the hospital was amazing. The lighting, the blurry eyes, the rain, the anxiety... MAN! PERFECT!The end of the movie wraps up pretty neatly. Loki hears Keller blowing the whistle and we know that he finds Keller, and we know that Keller goes to Jail (based on previous comments made by Loki in the hospital).This movie used the maze as a theme constantly. Think about how you would solve a maze on a piece of paper, following one trail until it dead ends and having to backtrack and pick a different branch, sometimes overlooking the right path until it is the only one left. That is how the plot played out, that is how each prisoner felt inside their prison. Beautiful.

reviewText: After watching Prisoners my reactions was simply, "Wow!”  It was an exhausting thrill ride that constantly forced you to asked yourself, "What if it was you?" , "What if it was your child?"  The answer to that question can leave you a little breathless... and maybe even frightened of your own reaction to the inherit desire to protect your children.  I must mention that there are some scenes that are intensely difficult to watch... you are basically seeing a man being tortured.  I am not one for gratuitous violence, but I can honestly say that I don't believe the violence in this film was gratuitous.  It was disgusting and painful, but it was far from disingenuous.The entire time that Hugh Jackman's character, Keller Dover, is torturing who he is absolutely certain has something to do with his missing daughter - Jackman plays crazy-obsessive so well that you begin to ask yourself, "Did this guy really do it, or is Keller torturing the wrong man?"  Especially when the tortured man whispers, "Help me," to Nancy Birch (the mother of the other missing daughter; and supremely played by Viola Davis).It is a very intense movie.  The writer (Aaron Guzikowski) and director (Denis Villeneuve) plotted out such a well-structured story, with actors who are incredibly believable.  There isn't a parental reaction that you can't empathize with:  Keller Dover/Hugh Jackman's obsessive need to defend and protect.  Franklin Birch/Terrence Howard willingness to find his daughter, but constantly questioning his own morality at torturing another human being.  Nancy Birch/Viola Davis just wants her daughter back; she supports Jackman's actions if there is even the slightest possibility of getting their children back.  Grace Dover/Maria Bello who is comatose with grief, but propels the story along for the detective (my favorite part of the movie was Jake Gyllenhaal).And then there's Jake Gyllenhaal character Detective Loki; who is just as obsessed with finding the missing girls as Jackman, but he doesn't lose sight of the law or his place in the justice system.  As I said, this was a masterfully crafted movie.  It used the plot and characters to move it along and tell the story.  When was the last time that happened in a movie?  There is no over the top CG, just great acting and superb story telling.  I loved it!This is the kind of movie where you have to pay attention because everything is a clue.  As I watched Jake Gyllenhaal interview Mrs. Millard, I kept thinking "how does a child abduction over ten years old have anything to do with the suspect who barely looks twenty?" ... but it was an integral part of discovering the culprit.Also, I’ve seen some reviews mention the language/cursing and I couldn’t help but think, this is a movie about a man who decides to torture another human being who may or may not have had anything to do with his daughter’s abduction, and the one thing that bothered you is the cursing… really??Watch this movie, but I don’t recommend this on a family movie night (too intense for the kiddies).  Prepare to yell at the TV (especially at the incredible ending), and cringe with frustration and hope.  I hope more movies rely on plot and characters.  Yes, please more like this!

reviewText: Prisoners (Denis Villeneuve, 2013)I'll be up front with you: I am writing the first sentences of this review, which I expect will be a very long one, without knowing what rating I will actually be giving Prisoners. I believe that somewhere over the course of the thousands of reviews I have written (Amazon is home to over six thousand of them as of this writing, on October 5, 2013, and I had been reviewing steadily for longer before I started posting there than I have been since I started, so you can do the math...) that has probably happened before...but I can't remember it, if it has. I have a great deal to mull over before figuring that out, I think. I liked it, overall; there is a great deal to like about it. It is surprisingly well-paced for having come out of a film culture where directors are actively encouraged to make their films about half as long as this one (this is the only film I have seen made in the last fifteen years that is this long that is not either (a) a musical, (b) a Shah Rukh Khan vehicle, or (c ) both of the above), it is unflinching in its examination of violence, its script is intelligent and multi-layered (though it does overplay its hand now and again), it is impeccably-cast, and I could keep going like this all night without really digging into the film at all. But it is not perfect, and while I admit I finished watching it less than an hour and a half before I am writing the opening words of this review, the more I think about the nagging questions I walked out of the theater with, the more they nag at me. Time will tell (and probably will, before I finish writing this review, which will probably be a few weeks from now—if I follow standard operating procedure with it, anyway) if they continue to nag, but the biggest thing that bothered me, and my first impression is that much of this comes from Jake Gyllenhaal being one of the male leads, is that I saw a lot of Zodiac in this movie. I also saw a lot of Snowtown, which is harder to explain away. That made some of what unfolded on the screen before me more predictable than, I think, it should have been; almost certainly more than screenwriter Aaron Guzikowski (Contraband) intended. But we shall see after I keep mulling it over; I'm going to go do some more of that right now.Plot: Keller Dover (X-Men's Hugh Jackman) and Frankin Burch (Hustle and Flow's Terrence Howard) are friends in the suburbs. They get together for Thanksgiving; their daughters go out, saying they're heading over to the other house to do whatever it is that preteen girls do away form the prying eyes of their parents. They never make it. Suspicion is immediately cast on a broken-down old camper that has been seen in the area; when the police track it down in the dark corner of a convenience store parking lot, they find its driver to be young mentally-challenged Alex Jones (The Good Heart's Paul Dano). The police, in the form of one Detective Loki (The Day After Tomorrow's Jake Gyllenhaal), interrogate Jones, but do not have enough evidence to go anywhere with it; he is ultimately released, leading Dover to take matters into his own hands. Initially, Burch goes along with Dover's plan for extracting information, but the longer things go one, the more Dover pulls away not only from Burch, but from the rest of his life. Eventually, people start noticing that Alex has gone missing, and Detective Loki's focus hones in on Dover.And now back to my initial paragraph, which I wrote five months before this one. About 80% of this movie is phenomenal, a thought-provoking journey into the motivations and actions of people who are driven to desperation. The other 20% feels as if it were tacked on for a commercial audience who would not be satisfied with that and needed some sort of conventional mystery to resolve. It's trite, relies on plot twists you've seen in half a hundred other movies of its ilk, and while it is as well-presented as the rest of the movie—these are all fine actors turning in fine performances, Villeneuve (Incendies) certainly knows his way around a camera, and  Roger Deakins was nominated for an Oscar for his chilling cinematography (he lost to, of course, Gravity)—it still feels kind of like the old Irving Pichel trick of “hey, we finished shooting a week early and have some extra stock, let's make another movie!”...except this time they stitched the two together, and the graft didn't quite take. The straight mystery at the end is watchable, but in juxtaposition to the drama/thriller/horror film that comes before it, it pales. Should you see it? Absolutely. Is it, as IMDB would have us believe as I am writing this in March 2014, one of the 250 best movies ever made (it is sitting at #249)? Not on your life. ***

reviewText: Directed by Dennis Villeneuve, this crime thriller received a poor review in the local paper, but a strong recommendation from a friend prompted me to see it.  The movie played at the Toronto Film Festival before its release. It was the top box office draw the first weekend after its release on September 20.At over 2.5 hours, "Prisoners" is long and begins slowly. The tension builds throughout, however, as the tangled plot develops. The film held my attention. In noting the commercial success of the movie, the "Los Angeles Times" aptly described it as a "head spinning hybrid combining elements that are rarely combined." These elements include noir and murder together with meditations on violence, vigilantism, religion, and parenting.The two lead characters, Keller Dover and Detective Laki are played respectively by Hugh Jackman and Jake Gyllenhall.  Dover is a home repair contractor and a fundamentalist Christian. Laki is a tight-lipped, hardbitten, and successful tattooed detective. Gyllenhall's portrayal is a highlight of the movie.Dover and his wife visit their friends and neighbors, the Birches, for Thanksgiving, and the two daughters of the couples are mysteriously abducted. The movie involves a search for the perpetrator with Laki the lead detective assigned to the case. Attention focuses on a young man, Alex Jones, (Paul Dano) who it turns out has the I.Q. of a boy of ten. When the police release Jones, Dover takes the law into his own hands and kidnaps and brutally beats him as the suspected abductor. The Birches back off from the cruelty but don't report Dover to the police. The convoluted plot develops through many twists as Laki works with determination to save the girls and find the kidnapper.There are several "prisoners" to give the movie its title, including the two abducted girls and Alex. Possibly the chief "prisoner" is Dover, who is an internal prisoner of his fear, anger and thirst for vengeance.The movie includes substantial and somewhat ersatz religious symbolism. Besides Dover's fundamentalism, (the hymn "What a Friend we have in Jesus" plays ironically throughout) the movie features a priest who is a sexual predator as well as characters who lose their religious faith when their young son dies of cancer. The primary focus, however, is on vengeance and viligantism.The strengths of the movie include Gyllenhall's acting, the noir setting, including cold and snowy rainy nights, frightening special effects, dramatic tension, and the foreboding musical score.  The weaknesses include the complex, coincidence-driven plot, and an over-straining for symbols and meaning.Given its hybrid character, and the mixed recommendations I received before seeing the film, viewers are likely to have differing responses to "Prisoners". I would not give it raves, but I found "Prisoners" well done and worth seeing.Robin Friedman
summary: A "Head Spinning Hybrid" of a Movie

reviewText: PRISONERS, (2013). This crime drama/thriller, set in contemporary smalltown Pennsylvania, USA, examines the responses of  parents of kidnapped children to their desperate situation.  As written by Denis Villeneuve and directed by Aaron Guzikowski, this is one star-spangled suspenser.To summarize the plot, let me quote from Warner Bros. Pictures, the releasing studio, as printed at IMDb:How far would you go to protect your family? Keller Dover is facing every parent's worst nightmare. His six-year-old daughter, Anna, is missing, together with her young friend, Joy, and as minutes turn to hours, panic sets in. The only lead is a dilapidated RV that had earlier been parked on their street. Heading the investigation, Detective Loki arrests its driver, Alex Jones, but a lack of evidence forces his release. As the police pursue multiple leads and pressure mounts, knowing his child's life is at stake the frantic Dover decides he has no choice but to take matters into his own hands. But just how far will this desperate father go to protect his family?Hugh Jackman, (WOLVERINE), as Keller Dover, turns in a towering performance that carries the picture.  Jake Gyllenhaal, (BROKEBACK MOUNTAIN), as Detective Loki, holds his own and then some, no easy thing.  Admired actor Terrence Howard (CRASH) plays Franklin Birch, father of Joy, the other missing girl.  Oscar-winning Viola Davis, (THE HELP), plays Nancy Birch, mother of Joy;  the Pennsylvania-born Maria Bello (A HISTORY OF VIOLENCE)  plays Grace Dover, mother of Anna.  Paul Dano plays Alex Jones, Oscar-winner Melissa Leo, (THE FIGHTER), plays Holly Jones, the aunt with whom he lives.  Dylan Minnette, who pops up everywhere playing teenage sons, plays Ralph, the Dovers' son.  Broadway favorite Len Cariou plays Father Patrick Dunn, an important supporting role.The film is long, at 153 minutes, and I sometimes thought it could be cut by at least 30-45 minutes, particularly in some distasteful scenes apparently designed to illustrate techniques of `enhanced interrogation.'  It also seems some of us are meant to hate Keller Dover from the opening, in which he encourages his son to shoot a deer.  It is the first day of the state approved hunting season, Thanksgiving, no less.  Dover seems an illustration of the perceived-in-some-quarters gun-toting survivalist politics of the rural, poor mountainous Appalachian spine of the state, sandwiched between the richer and more liberal Philadelphia and Pittsburgh. I hated Dover throughout the picture, only to realize when I thought it over later that he was on to something all along.  Which is quite a feat of script-writing.  The presence of Melissa Leo in a supporting part is another illustration of the DePue dictum of casting: the presence of an actor more important/expensive than the part seems to require is a tipoff that the part's going to be more important than you think.  The squeamish might want to close their eyes sometimes, but thriller lovers will not want to miss this one.
summary: A Chilller to the End, and Then Some

reviewText: Two young girls are abducted after a Thanksgiving meal where their two families are celebrating in the home of one of them.  The girls have wandered outside to play and go unnoticed for some time while the families enjoy one another's company.  Eventually, people begin to notice their absence and then, very quickly, panic sets in and the two fathers (Hugh Jackman and Terrence Howard) run off to look for them.  In the meantime Jackman's son remembers that, earlier, the girls were fascinated by a motorhome parked a little way down the street when they had gone out prior to dinner.  He tells his father and they go to look for the motorhome, which is now gone.Enter the police, primarily in the form of Jake Gyllenhaal, who quickly locate the motorhome and its sole occupant and bring him into custody.  However, when they try to interrogate him they find that he has the mental age of a 10 year old and are forced to release him after a forensic search shows no physical evidence of the missing girls in the vehicle.This incenses Jackman's character who decides to take matters into his own hands with grim consequences!  This film examines the obvious toll on all the members of a family whose child has been abducted and we witness the harrowing aftermath for all concerned as the tragedy unfolds before our eyes.  The movie seems more to have echoes of `Dead Zone' rather than `Taken', as it scrutinizes the almost Gothic weirdness of small town America beneath the Norman Rockwell homespun, 'apple pie' type images that we are often fed.And it's all the more disturbing in the wake of the recent revelations, in Austria, America and elsewhere of kidnappings, imprisonment and even the enslavement of abducted children who seem simply to disappear into thin air and the twisted logic of the individuals who perpetrate this evil, often seeking to mitigate their actions in religious terms!The whole cast puts in very convincing performances and this, together with an intelligent script, makes for horribly compelling viewing but one you probably won’t want to repeat any time soon!

reviewText: Prisoners is an outstanding new mystery/thriller that manages to sustain its tension right to the last second.If you have seen the trailer, you know quite a bit about Prisoners.Hugh Jackman plays Keller Dover, a construction worker who lives in a quiet New England suburb with his wife (Maria Bello), teenage son, and six year old daughter. While spending Thanksgiving with the family of his life-long friend and neighbor, Franklin Birch (Terrance Howard), Keller and Franklin discover that both of their daughters are suddenly missing.After frantically searching the area, the only lead they have is a strange RV that was parked in the area.With the help of Detective Loki (Jake Gyllenhaal) and the police, they are able to track down the RV and apprehend a suspect (Paul Dano), but due to his mental incapacity and lack of evidence, he is released.This sends Prisoners in a harrowing new direction as Keller and Franklin wade through some ethically murky waters in the search for their daughters.Prisoners does a phenomenal job of keeping its cards close to the vest.In its transition from drama to revenge thriller, director Denis Villenuve and writer Aaron Guzikowski do not force the film in any one direction continuously playing with the audience's sensibilities.Villenuve and Guzikowski are relative newcomers to the scene, although Villenuve did helm the 2010 Best Foreign Film Oscar nominee, Incendies.This is also a very smart movie in that it is not a run of the mill type of thriller.Several nuanced touches and motifs present themselves that allow the film to be absorbed to a deeper level, resulting in a film that stays with you long after you leave the theater.Take special note of the film's opening scene and revisit it after having seen the movie for a taste of what I'm talking about.ImageHoly smokes! Look at all of those awards...sorry Paul Dano.The film manages the gripping tone of films like Silence of the Lambs or Zodiac.The film also looks great.It was shot by Roger Deakins, known for his work with the Coen Brothers on most of their projects.With Prisoners, Deakins uses his static and deliberate camera movements to enhance every suspenseful opportunity.It's a tremendously well-crafted picture and a finely acted one as well.The film boasts Academy Award winners and nominees aplenty, and all of them are looking for more in this film.Gyllanhaal is especially good at elevating the traditional detective character to something more relatable, raw, and grounded.This is, however, Jackman's movie in every way.He takes the audience on a wild ride of emotion bringing just the right amount of crazy to keep us from judging his choices too harshly.Prisoners is not just a good start to the fall movie season, it sets the bar.Few films offer such chilling emotion, engrossing action, and captivating performances, especially with running times of 158 minutes!This is truly an excellent film.APrisoners is rated R an has a running time of 2 hours and 38 minutes.Use the restroom before you start it because you won't want to miss a second of it.

reviewText: Denis Villeneuve’s Prisoners is way better than it looks in the trailer. The trailer seems to give away all the secrets of the film upfront; it portrays the film as lacking depth, but in reality, it’s just the trailer that misleads. There is much more to Prisoners than one may anticipate.The film stars Hugh Jackman (surprise, surprise) as Keller Dover. Jackman is having an over-exposure problem at this moment in his career. As the actor seems to appear in every other film released these days, this creates questions that shouldn’t exist like, “What is the Wolverine doing in this movie Prisoners?” Nonetheless Jackman delivers a solid, if not dimensional performance. His energy keeps the movie constantly driving forward.The film opens with two working class families getting together to celebrate Thanksgiving. Festivities abound, but while the responsible adults of the film have their attentions focused elsewhere, their two little girls run outside to play, unchaperoned. By the time the girls’ absence is noticed, it’s too late. The girls are gone. They have been taken. The major conflict of the film then is how to get the girls back alive.This job falls on Detective Loki, (Jake Gyllenhaal) but when Loki fails to produce results quickly enough, Keller Dover decides to take the search for the girls, and for civil justice, into his own hands. Performance-wise, Gyllenhaal as Loki is the highlight of the film. He maintains a subtle, calm composure, which contrasts Keller’s (Jackman’s) constant flying-off-the-rails. Loki shows a certain vulnerability while still being able to pull off fast-pace action sequences in an authentic, belivable way. He is very enjoyable to watch.The actual visual experience of Villeneuve’s films is very important. His 2010 film Incendies made full use of wide and vast cinematography applied in exotic landscapes. This visual imagery captivated, but all the technique was there to serve the story, the plot developments, the characters. Incendies is a masterfully crafted tragedy and Villeneuve’s commanding technique is evident too throughout Prisoners.Like Incendies the filters and tones that are applied to the film, as in the actual visual images on screen, are gloomy and sepia-toned. There’s not a single sunny sky, a warm day, an orderly room. Sets are designed to feel dark and empty, the best scenes use sets that play with space, showing both the abundance of vacant space for some characters, while still emphasizing the feeling of enclosure felt by others. The use of light and dark, order and disorder, space, all things that cradle the actors performances, are created by Villeneuve, expertly.The suspense of the film continues all the way to the very end as Keller Dover’s untamed compulsion to find the missing girls leads to a perfectly executed, nail biter of an ending.Get more at getthebonesaw.blogspot.com

reviewText: "Prisoners" is a bleak, gripping mystery thriller that stays with you. It's a long and involving tale of two rural Pennsylvania families devastated by the theft of their young daughters on Thanksgiving Day and of a man so driven by the loss that he is willing to do almost anything to rescue them, consequences be damned. Comparisons to the films "Mystic River," "Gone Baby Gone," and "Silence of the Lambs" are inevitable, but don't let the fact that it's a genre picture deter you. The twists and turns of this confidently plotted drama will have you riveted to your seat, and the final scenes will give you more than one shock.The film's running time of two-and-a-half hours is fully justified; there isn't a wasted moment on screen. I won't give away any details (if you want a plot synopsis, there's always Wikipedia), but be prepared to be put through an emotional wringer. The film, set in the late fall, is suffused with a wintery aura of dread and menace. The deliberate pace never lets us forget the seemingly endless wait that families of kidnapping victims must endure. Every clue that is dropped pitches us from hope into despair and back again. And a warning is in order: there are brutal scenes of torture that are deeply disturbing."Prisoners" is filled with searing performances by an A-list of Hollywood's finest actors, led by Hugh Jackman as a desperate father who becomes a frightening mirror image of the monsters he pursues and Jake Gyllenhaal as a dogged detective who confronts a labyrinthine web of horror and depravity. The other anguished parents are heartbreakingly played by Maria Bello, Terrence Howard, and Viola Davis, while Oscar-winner Melissa Leo appears as the mother of a disabled man, portrayed by Paul Dano, who is a prime suspect in the girls' disappearance. All of these actors, together with the film, director Denis Villeneuve, and screenwriter Aaron Guzikowski, will earn consideration for Academy Awards in 2014.
summary: A dark, complex, challenging film with a superb cast

reviewText: Prisoners is a prime example of why I will never understand Hollywood. You've got a truly great story, an all-star cast, and a world renowned Director, making his American debut. Prisoners was considered to be an Oscar caliber film before it was even released, yet for some reason they had to make it nearly three hours long. If there was enough story for a three hour film, then I'd be all for it, but Prisoners has a good 45 minutes worth of repetitiveness, that does nothing to help the movie, in fact, it takes something away from the film. The story begins on Thanksgiving, when two little girls go outside to play and disappear. Feeling that the police aren't doing enough to find the kids, one father (Hugh Jackman) decides to take matters into his own hands. Hugh Jackman stars in a role I wouldn't have imagined him playing in a million years. Based on his other roles and what I know about the man, this doesn't even seem like the kind of role he'd be interested in, but he gives one of the strongest performances I've seen all year, I really didn't know he had that in him. Jackman is paired by Jake Gyllenhaal, another guy who I couldn't see playing a tough as nails police detective, but he too surprised, giving a very strong performance. The cast isn't the problem and the story isn't the problem, what bothered me about this film was how much of it was unnecessary. Did we really need dozens of scenes with Jackman and Dano or all the talk and sadness amongst the families? This was a great all-around movie, but it was so long, that by the end, I'd stopped caring about what was happening and just wanted it to be over. Don't get me wrong, I highly recommend this film for a unique twist on classic story, great performances from an unlikely cast, and the work of a Director who his known around the world for his signature style, but just a word of caution. Prisoners is a very long film, that at many points seems to go around in circles. When they eventually do get to the point, it's outstanding, but it takes a while to get there.

reviewText: *** This review may contain spoilers ***Rating: 3.5 out of 5.0Canadian director Denis Villeneuve is back with another densely plotted movie with 'Prisoners'. His 2011 'Incendies' was interesting but ultimately full of too many scenes which forced the viewer to suspend one's disbelief, one too many times. 'Prisoners' also has some questionable plot points but it's eminently more entertaining than Incendies.Villeneuve proffers up an interesting protagonist, Keller Dover (played by an intense Hugh Jackman), a survivalist type, who has no compunctions about teaching his son how to shoot a deer, on a hunting trip, depicted at the beginning of the film. While Jackman has a lot to work with depicting the hot-head Keller, Terrence Howard has little to do playing Franklin Birch, Keller's exact opposite: a passive (and thinly drawn) middle class black professional. The break into Act II occurs when Keller's and Birch's daughters are abducted after disappearing from the Birch family home.Since an RV was parked right near where the girls disappeared, the driver ends up as the number one suspect. The police soon track the driver down at a rest stop and he tries to escape by eluding a police blockade with his RV. The driver turns out to be Alex Jones, who on the surface appears to be mentally feeble. When Detective Loki (Jake Gyllenhaal) can find no evidence linking Alex to the girls' abduction and concludes he doesn't have the mental capacity to kidnap the girls, he's forced to release him, and allow him to return to the residence of Holly Jones, his aunt, a creepy senior, expertly played by Melissa Leo.A good deal of 'Prisoners' revolves around Keller's abduction and subsequent imprisonment of Alex, who he believes knows where the kidnapped girls are. Keller insists that Alex told him "they didn't cry until I left them," when Keller tries to choke him at the time he's released by the police, in front of a multitude of TV news reporters (no one else hears what Alex says to Keller).Before discussing the issue of Alex's refusal to talk, there are two red herrings in the plot, designed to throw you off track. Both involve Detective Loki's interaction with two suspects. The first is a priest who's on parole for a sex crime--out of the blue Loki finds a bound, deceased man in the priest's basement. The priest claims that he was forced to kill the man after he revealed (during confession) that he was a serial killer, who would kill again. Later, Loki chases after a suspicious man seen at a vigil for the missing girls, in front of the Birch's home. He turns out to be a wannabe serial killer, Taylor, who breaks into the family houses of real serial killer's victims and steals their clothes. Loki, who supposedly has solved all of his cases, blows this one, after Taylor grabs one of Loki's deputy's guns and shoots himself in the mouth.Even if you believe in both these incredible turn of events, one is hard pressed to believe in the film's main premise--that Alex would refuse to talk, despite being tortured for days by Keller. SUPER SPOILERS AHEAD. One of the arguments that Alex doesn't talk is because he is mentally handicapped. But that's debunked by the points Keller raises--he knew about the girls and told Keller; he tried to escape from the police in his RV and had a driver's license and was able to drive.Another reason (which seems to be suggested by the filmmakers) is that he's under the spell of Aunt Holly and is either a) afraid of her, b) evil like her, or c) both. He seemingly is given a free pass at film's end, despite Keller's statement that he confessed that he basically knew where the girls were (the free pass may be due to the fact that Keller's credibility was completely suspect, by breaking the law by abducting him). Still, while possible, I still think it's unlikely that Alex would never have turned against the old lady. Think of the child abduction case of Steven Stayner. He was imprisoned for seven years but when given the opportunity, he escaped and saved a newly abducted child. Alex was the first child abducted by Holly and her husband and the filmmakers would like us to believe he was psychologically beholden to his captor. But in real life, the Stayner case proves the opposite. I would like to think the desire for freedom would still burn in Alex's breast and his abduction by Keller would have been the perfect opportunity for him to spill the beans about his aunt. By confessing, he's smart enough to know that Aunt Holly would immediately be taken into custody and he would not have to be afraid of her anymore.Prisoners represents a critique of those who embrace the survivalist mentality and act as vigilantes. We expect Keller to save his daughter but actually Detective Loki does so after racing to the hospital and saving Keller's daughter from poisoning (Loki's big car race is not that exciting, since the outcome is pretty much expected). Instead, Keller underestimates Holly who turns out to be responsible for the girls' abduction as well as numerous other serial killings. Keller ends up in that hole and my interpretation of the abrupt (but clever) ending, is that he WILL rescue Keller, and let him face the music.'Prisoners' indeed will drag you into its electrically-charged story and keep you at the edge of your seat to the end. The supporting players, those who play the wives and children of Keller and Franklin, do quite well, but are saddled by underdeveloped parts. Ultimately, you will have to overlook the red herrings and the main premise that the feeble (or perhaps not so feeble) Alex, will not crack under torture. I prefer to believe that he would, as most people would in that situation.
summary: An exciting serial killer thriller but I had trouble believing torture victim wouldn't crack

reviewText: After viewing "Prisoners" opening night in the theater with a couple of friends, I turned to them during the closing credits and said "I feel like I've just been through a ten round prize fight".  It had been a long time since I'd seen a movie that battered my emotions quite as much as this one.For a basic plot summary, "Prisoners" opens on a typical Thanksgiving day in what just might be your (the viewers') neighborhood.  Instead of the normal revelry and family cheer, however, the daughters of Keller Dover (Hugh Jackman) and Franklin Birch (Terrence Howard) are kidnapped.  When detective Loki (Jake Gyllenhaal) finds a very strange suspect (Paul Dano), it jump-starts the case in a terrifying direction that goes further into the realm of gritty reality than most films will show.I consider "Prisoners" to be one of the best films I've ever seen (I don't even want to put a genre to it, as that would be such a disservice to its breadth) because it is so perfect on both the plot and character levels.Plot-wise, it is a simple kidnapping story (one that has been utilized numerous times in cinema), yet director Dennis Villeneuve pushes its boundaries to the very max.  Just when you think you have the film pinned down, it manages to surprise you and go in another direction.  Yet, everything makes logical sense and feels "real" at the same time.That being said, the kidnapping plot itself (while brilliant) is not even the primary focus of the film.  Instead, it is the characters reactions to the events, making viewers ponder how we would react in similar situations.  The main focus here is on Dover and Loki, but each character adds a very specifically nuanced emotion to the overall mix.  The result is drama the likes of which is rarely seen (and sustained for nearly two and a half hours) on the big screen.I rarely watch a movie twice within the span of a year, but when "Prisoners" comes out to home video I will be snapping it up in an instant to watch with others who I know will appreciate the eerie genius of the experience.  I know that many, many more movies will be released between now and "awards season" (aka Academy Awards), but it would be a crying shame if this masterpiece isn't highly represented.  For the rest of the year, I'll be hard-pressed to see one better.
summary: A Simple Premise, Yet Oh So Complex Emotionally
